A OneFord globally developed vehicle, the new-generation Transit was designed by [[Ford of Europe]] and co-developed with Ford in North America. In a break from the previous generation of the Transit, there are two distinct body forms: *'''Mid-size front wheel drive:''' now a distinct model, branded [[Ford Transit Custom|'''Transit/Tourneo Custom''']]. It is intended to compete with vehicles such as the [[Mercedes-Benz Vito|Mercedes-Benz Vito/Viano]] and [[Volkswagen Transporter (T5)|Volkswagen Transporter T5]]. *'''Full size rear wheel drive:''' a full size version, to enable Transit to better replace the outgoing twenty-year-old [[Ford E-Series|Econoline/E-Series]] in the North American market.{{cite web |url=http://www.ford.com/commercial-trucks/transit/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=1 June 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130802102427/http://www.ford.com/commercial-trucks/transit/ |archivedate=2 August 2013 |df=dmy-all }} While the front-wheel drive V347 Transit was sold alongside the E-Series in Mexico starting in 2007 (replacing the Freestar minivan), this generation of the Transit is the first to be officially sold in the United States and Canada. As part of the development cycle, Ford loaned examples of the previous-generation (V347/348) Transit to high-mileage drivers in the United States for evaluation purposes and durability testing. Both versions external design look evolved from the New Edge styling used from the previous-generation model to the ''[[Kinetic Design|Kinetic]]'' design adopted by the OneFord global models since 2010; the interior drew cues from the third generation [[Ford Focus (third generation)|Ford Focus]]. === Model configuration === The new Transit is available in cargo van and chassis/cutaway cab configurations. In a significant departure from the E-Series, but standard for existing rest of world versions, Transit vans/wagons come in three different roof heights; extended-wheelbase vans are available with dual rear wheels. It was released in North America in the summer of 2014, released as a 2015 model. As with the much smaller Transit Connect, passenger versions are marketed under a singular Transit nameplate rather than the Tourneo name seen globally. Outside of North America, much of the Transit engine lineup and drivetrain configurations are retained from the previous generation. For the United States and Canada, the four cylinder engines and manual transmission are not offered; in these markets only the 180-hp 3.2L Duratorq I5 diesel (branded as a PowerStroke) is shared with global-market models. For North America, the standard engine is a 275-hp 3.7L [[Ford Cyclone engine#Duratec 37|Ti-VCT]] V6 (shared with the [[Ford F series|F-Series]] and Police Interceptor version of the Ford Explorer) and an optional 320-hp 3.5L [[Ford Ecoboost engine#3.5 L EcoBoost V6|EcoBoost]] V6 shared with the F-150 and D3-platform vehicles. All versions in North America are specified with a 6-speed automatic transmission and rear-wheel drivetrain. The 3.7L Ti-VCT V6 can be converted to run on [[compressed natural gas]] or [[liquefied petroleum gas]] with an optional Gaseous Engine Prep Package.{{cite web |title=2014 Transit: Alternative Fuel Capability |url=http://www.ford.com/commercial-trucks/transit/2014/features/#page=Feature13 |publisher=Ford Motor Company |accessdate=1 June 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130603022724/http://www.ford.com/commercial-trucks/transit/2014/features/#page=Feature13 |archivedate=3 June 2013 |df=dmy-all }} In North America, 4x4 conversions are done through factory-supported third party installers. Each Transit model saw at least at a 600 lb. increase in maximum payload capability over the comparable E-Series/Econoline model it replaced. The Transit's body makes extensive use of boron steel in its construction.{{cite web | title=ALL-NEW FORD TRANSIT: BETTER GAS MILEAGE THAN E-SERIES; BEST-IN-CLASS GAS ENGINE TORQUE, CARGO CAPACITY |url=https://media.ford.com/content/fordmedia/fna/us/en/news/2014/06/04/all-new-ford-transit.html |publisher=Ford Motor Company |accessdate=7 August 2018}} === Production === Worldwide production of Ford Transits takes place in two facilities; all European and Asian Transit production is from [[Ford Otosan]] in [[Kocaeli Province]], Turkey; this factory will also provide a percentage of global exports. North American and South American production is primarily sourced from [[Ford Kansas City Assembly Plant|Kansas City Assembly]] in [[Claycomo, Missouri]] on the lines used for the previous generation [[Ford Escape]]; production at the Kansas City Assembly Plant began on 30 April 2014.{{cite web |url=https://media.ford.com/content/fordmedia/fna/us/en/news/2014/04/30/new-kansas-city-employees-celebrate-start-of-2015-transit-production.html |title=2,000 New Ford Kansas City Employees Celebrate Start of Production of Game-Changing 2015 Ford Transit Van |work=ford.com}} {{clear}} == Chinese production (2006–2017) == {{Infobox automobile |image=Ford Transit III China 2012-04-22.jpg |name=Ford Transit (China) |assembly=[[Nanchang]], China ([[Jiangling Motors|Jiangling]]) |production=2006–2017 |wheelbase={{convert|111.61|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} (SWB)/{{convert|140.55|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} (LWB) |length={{convert|213.31|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |width={{convert|77.27|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |body_style=4-door [[van]] |height={{convert|87.87|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |platform=VE83 |layout=[[FR layout]] |engine = '''Diesel engines'''
2.8L [[List of Isuzu engines|4JB1]] [[Inline-four engine|I4]]
'''Petrol engines'''
2.4L [[Mitsubishi Sirius engine|4G64]] [[Inline-four engine|I4]] |transmission=5-speed manual |weight={{convert|1920|-|2030|kg|lb|0|abbr=on}} |sp=uk }} The Ford Transit VJX6541DK-M is a Chinese market specific version, and is based on the third generation VE6/VE94 platform. This generation is only built in [[Nanchang]] by [[Jiangling Motors]] and is reserved for the Chinese domestic market. Remarkable are the much larger headlights and the larger grille. The model was launched to the market in 2006. Overall, the generation has 70 improvements to its predecessor. The interior has been changed and made more ergonomic. Power windows are standard, but ABS is optional. The Chinese Transit is available with two diesel engines and one petrol. One of them has a power of 67.6 kW (Type JX493ZQ3), the other 68 kW (JX493ZQ4). Both diesels have a capacity of 2,771 cc. The later diesel version has a common-rail 2.8-litre unit (with turbocharger and intercooler) that produces 80–85 kW. The Petrol version uses a Mitsubishi 4G64S4N Engine 92 kW inline-four motor.{{citation needed|date=November 2012}} The top speed is specified at {{convert|68.35|mph|km/h|0|abbr=on}}. The Chinese Transits have a [[Vehicle Identification Number|VIN]] in following form: LJXBMCH1××T××××××. [[File:SZ Tour Street 90412 救護車 Ambulance.JPG|thumb|left|Ford Transit Ambulance in Shenzhen, Guangdong Province]] The European 2006 Ford Transit went into production in 2008. On the Chinese market it is known as the ''New Transit''. It is offered parallel to the 2006 China generation. The two facilities are currently manufacturing 300,000 units annually. Ford and Jiangling want to open a third plant in late 2012 to increase the annual production to further 3,000 units.{{cite web |author=Sun Press |url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/nm/20100718/bs_nm/us_ford_jiangling_china |title=Ford breaks ground on $300 million China plant |publisher=Yahoo! News |date=18 July 2010 |accessdate=26 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100722122441/http://news.yahoo.com/s/nm/20100718/bs_nm/us_ford_jiangling_china |archivedate=22 July 2010}} In January 2010, the [[2009–2010 Toyota vehicle recalls|Toyota recalls]] affected the products of the Ford Group because Ford used the same supplier ([[CTS Corporation]]). It was suspected that the accelerator pedals were defective and posed a danger. About 1600 Ford Transits of the 2006 China generation were affected by the recall.{{cite web |last=Peskett |first=Karl |url=http://www.caradvice.com.au/55108/ford-transit-production-in-china-also-stopped-due-to-pedal-issues/ |title=Ford Transit production in China also stopped due to pedal issues |publisher=Car Advice |date=30 January 2010 |accessdate=26 July 2010}} The European models of the VE6 and VE8 generation can be given an aftermarket facelift to the Chinese version. This needs the Chinese components and manual skills. Production finally came to an end in 2017.{{cite web |url=http://foongleongsoon.blogspot.com/2007/07/ford-transit-facelift-parts-arrived.html |title=Ford Transit facelift parts arrived! |publisher=Foongleongsoon.blogspot.com |date=18 July 2007 |accessdate=26 July 2010}} ===JMC Teshun=== {{main article|JMC Teshun}} [[File:JMC Teshun.jpg|thumb|left|JMC Teshun in Shanghai]] Starting from May 2017, a version of the old Transit manufactured by [[Jiangling Motors|JMC]] was rebadged and slightly redesigned. The rebadged version is called the '''JMC Teshun'''. Pricing ranges from 99,800 yuan to 139,200 yuan. {{cite web|url=https://carnewschina.com/2016/10/10/jmc-is-going-stormtrooper-with-new-old-mini-van/|title=JMC Is Going Stormtrooper With New-Old Mini Van}} {{cite web|url=https://carnewschina.com/2017/05/12/jmc-teshun-ford-tansit-turned-storm-trooper/|title=The JMC Teshun Is A Ford Tansit Turned Storm Trooper}} {{clear}} == Variants == === County 4x4 === [[File:Ford Transit County 4x4.jpg|thumb|left|Mk3 County 4x4 Transit]] A handful of companies offered four-wheel-drive conversions, such as County Tractors of Knighton in Powys,{{cite web |title=History |url=http://www.transitcounty4x4.co.uk/ |publisher=Ford Transit County 4X4 |accessdate=17 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111108002600/http://www.transitcounty4x4.co.uk/ |archivedate=8 November 2011 |df=dmy-all }} who converted vans on behalf of Ford as a [[Special Vehicle Operations]] factory option. The first Transit County models were based on the Mk2 Transit model, both long and short wheelbase. The conversion used a [[Dana Holding Corporation|Dana]] 44F front axle and a NP208 transfer box, both lifted from the Ford Bronco, coupled to the regular Transit engine, gearbox and rear axle using three custom propshafts. The Transit rear axle was retained, mounted to a rear subframe or 'lift cradle' to give the extra ride height. Other modifications were 16-inch wheel rims, locking front hubs, a heavy-duty steering box and 305 mm diameter front brake discs. With the introduction of the Mk3 Transit in 1986 came the next generation of the County 4x4. This would prove to be a very popular and successful version of the County Transit 4x4, and the last to use the Dana beam axle layout. Later County 4x4 models switched to using an independent front suspension setup which was inherently more complex in design than the earlier beam axle models. Later panel vans also lost the twin-wheel rear axle that had been fitted on earlier LWB versions. Mainly used by utility companies such as National Grid, the Ministry Of Defence, and by mountain rescue teams, the Transit County 4x4 proved to be a capable vehicle both on and off road, with the ability to carry both crew and equipment just about anywhere. Design and supply of drivetrain components for County 4x4 models passed to Countytrac, a division of M.J. Allen Ltd, who are still involved in the development of the latest Mk7 AWD Transit and Connect models.{{Clear left}} === Tourneo === [[File:Metropolitan Police Ford Tourneo.JPG|thumb|left|Ford Tourneo with [[Metropolitan Police]]]] [[File:Ford Tourneo, Mark 5, rear view.jpg|thumb|right|Ford Tourneo]] Introduced as part of the 1995 redesign of the Transit, the Tourneo is a Transit-based 8 or 9-seat minibus, but over the years has become increasingly better trimmed up to the point where it can almost be classified as a large MPV. Featuring back seats and back windows similar to a [[minivan]], the Tourneo is also considered an [[Executive car|executive]] transport vehicle and is often supplied with alloy wheels. Since its introduction, the Tourneo has followed the same development cycle as the Transit; both versions receive updates at the same time. A smaller minivan version of the Tourneo was introduced in 2002; branded the [[Ford Transit Connect#Tourneo Connect|Tourneo Connect]], it was based on the Transit Connect [[mini MPV]]. {{clear}} == References == {{reflist|30em}} == External links == {{Commons category|Ford Transit}} *[http://www.ford.com.au/commercial/all-new-transit Official Australia Ford All-new Transit website] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090420010241/http://www.ford.co.uk/Commercialvehicles/Transit Official UK Ford Transit website] *[http://www.ford.com/commercial-trucks/transitcommercial/?searchid=210121585|14400819985|119364243&ef_id=VSE-PgAABKj97nwq:20150405135718:s USA Ford Transit website] {{Early European Ford vehicles}} {{Modern European Ford vehicles}} {{FordEurope}} {{Modern North American Ford trucks}} {{Ford}} [[Category:Ford vehicles|Transit]] [[Category:Ford of Europe vehicles|Transit]] [[Category:All-wheel-drive vehicles]] [[Category:Cars of Turkey]] [[Category:Flexible-fuel vehicles]] [[Category:Front-wheel-drive vehicles]] [[Category:Minibuses]] [[Category:Motor vehicles manufactured in the United States]] [[Category:Police vehicles]] [[Category:Rear-wheel-drive vehicles]] [[Category:Road vehicles manufactured in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:School bus chassis]] [[Category:Vans]] [[Category:Vehicles introduced in 1965]]

[[File:Spigelia genuflexa geocarpy.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|Geocarpy in ''[[Spigelia genuflexa]]'']] [[File:Peanut 9417.jpg|thumb|Peanut fruit have formed below the ground.]]
'''Geocarpy''' is "an extremely rare means of plant reproduction",<ref>{{cite book |author1=J. D. Skinner |author2=Christian T. Chimimba |year=2005 |title=The Mammals of the Southern African Sub-region |publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]] |isbn=9780521844185 |chapter=Order Tubulidentata |pages=35–40 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iqwEYkTDZf4C&pg=PA39}}</ref> in which [[plant]]s produce [[Diaspore (botany)|diaspores]] within the [[soil]].<ref name="Oudtshoorn">{{cite book |author=Karen van Rheede van Oudtshoorn & Margaretha W. Van Rooyen |year=1999 |title=Dispersal Biology of Desert Plants |publisher=[[Springer Science+Business Media|Springer]] |isbn=978-3-540-64886-4 |chapter=Geocarpy |pages=117–118 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bdTfBfsl-DcC&pg=PA117}}</ref> This may occur with subterranean flowers (protogeocarpy), or from aerial flowers, which penetrate the soil after flowering (hysterocarpy). It has [[evolution|evolved]] as an effective means of ensuring a suitable environment for the plant's offspring.<ref name="Oudtshoorn"/>
Geocarpy is also linked with [[solifluction]] soils, where rapid thawing and freezing of surface soil causes almost continuous movement.<ref name=Agnew>{{cite journal|last1=Agnew|first1=A.D.Q.|last2=Hedberg|first2=O.|title=Georcapy as an adaptation to afroalpine solifluction soils|journal=Journal of The East Africa Natural History Society and National Museum|date=1969|volume=XXVII|issue=3|page=215|url=https://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/content/part/EANHS/XXVII_No.3_118__215_1969_Agnew.pdf|accessdate=14 September 2015}}</ref> This phenomenon is prevalent in high altitude areas of [[East Africa]].<ref name=Agnew /> In order to reproduce, geocarpic plants bend their stems so that the fruit can be embedded in the soil during the freezing process while the fruit is still attached to the plant itself.<ref name=Agnew />
Geocarpy is most frequent in [[tropics|tropical]] or [[semi-desert]] areas,<ref name="Oudtshoorn"/> and geocarpic species may be found in the families [[Araceae]], [[Begoniaceae]], [[Brassicaceae]] (Cruciferae), [[Callitrichaceae]], [[Convolvulaceae]], [[Cucurbitaceae]], [[Fabaceae]] (Leguminosae), [[Loganiaceae]], [[Moraceae]] and [[Rubiaceae]].<ref name="Oudtshoorn"/><ref name="Brassicaceae">{{cite book |editor1=Renate Schmidt |editor2=Ian Bancroft |year=2010 |title=Genetics and Genomics of the Brassicaceae |volume=9 |series=Plant Genetics and Genomics |publisher=[[Springer Science+Business Media|Springer]] |isbn=9781441971180 |chapter=Brassicaceae in agriculture |author=Suzanne I. Warwick |pages=33–66 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tMYiyo0A4XAC&pg=PA42}}</ref><ref name="Popovkin">{{cite journal |author1=Alex V. Popovkin |author2=Katherine G. Mathews |author3=José Carlos Mendes Santos |author4=M. Carmen Molina |author5=Lena Struwe |year=2011 |title=''Spigelia genuflexa'' (Loganiaceae), a new geocarpic species from the Atlantic forest of northeastern Bahia, Brazil |journal=[[PhytoKeys]] |volume=6 |pages=47–65 |doi=10.3897/phytokeys.6.1654}}</ref> The best-known example is the [[peanut]], ''Arachis hypogaea''.

'''Hi-VAWT''' is a [[renewable energy]] solutions provider headquartered in [[Linkou District]], [[New Taipei City]], [[Taiwan]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Hi-VAWT info|url=http://www.verticalwindturbineinfo.com/vawt-manufacturers/hi-vawt-vertical-wind-turbines/}}</ref> Hi-VAWT has installations in many countries/territories worldwide (Taiwan, [[China]], [[Japan]], [[South Korea]], [[Hong Kong]], [[India]], [[Malaysia]], [[Australia]], [[New Zealand]], [[South Africa]], [[Spain]], [[Austria]], [[Czech Republic]], [[Italy]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Green thinking - Etneo Energy Italy VAWT |url=http://www.etneoenergy.com/wind.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717194550/http://www.etneoenergy.com/wind.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2011-07-17 }}</ref> [[Germany]], [[Poland]],<ref>{{cite web|title=WPIP partners |url=http://www.wpip.pl/hi-vawt,835,l2.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305081539/http://www.wpip.pl/hi-vawt%2C835%2Cl2.html |archivedate=2016-03-05 |df= }}</ref> [[Guam]], [[Hawaii]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Aloha Energy Group|url=http://www.alohaenergygroup.com/products/small-wind-turbines}}</ref> [[United States|the USA]],<ref>{{cite web|title=With long paybacks, vertical turbines still a tough sell|url=http://www.midwestenergynews.com/2012/01/04/small-wind-turbines/}}</ref> Jamaica <ref>{{cite web|title=Wind Energy - Small Wind Focus Jamaica |url=http://www.pcj.com/dnn/Portals/0/Documents/Small%20wind%20presentation%20-%20March%203%202011.pdf }}{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> and [[Canada]]),<ref>{{cite web|title=Hi-VAWT DS-3000 Photo Gallery|url=http://www.hi-vawt.com.tw/en/ds3000w_photogallery.html}}</ref> and on every continent including Antarctica,.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hi-VAWT DS-300 Project Gallery|url=http://www.hi-vawt.com.tw/en/ds300w_projectgallery.html}}</ref> The company also a member of Taiwan Wind Turbine Industry Association.<ref>{{cite web|title=About TWTIA |url=http://www.twtia.org.tw/english/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130504051619/http://www.twtia.org.tw/english/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-05-04 }}</ref>
Hi-VAWT's turbines utilize a combined [[Darrieus wind turbine|Darrieus]] and [[Savonius wind turbine]]. Savonius turbine is a drag-type wind turbine that perform well under low-wind speed condition, while Darrieus turbine is a lift-type wind turbine that perform best at high-wind speed condition. The vertical axis allowing the turbine to take wind from all directions simultaneously. While the combo-blades provide a self-starting performance while maintain a good working condition in higher wind speed situation.<ref>{{cite web|title=Small Scale Wind Turbines Optimized for Low Wind Speeds|url=https://kb.osu.edu/dspace/bitstream/handle/1811/45531/Hayes_Proceedings_Paper.pdf?sequence=1}}</ref>
==Locations== Hi-VAWT business organization was started and is headquartered in [[Linkou District]], [[New Taipei City]], [[Taiwan]]. The company also has offices/distributors in China,<ref>{{cite web|title=Hi-VAWT China official website|url=http://www.hi-vawt.com/page/ch_welcome.html}}</ref> South Korea,<ref>{{cite web|title=Hi-Energy Korea official website|url=http://www.hi-energy.co.kr}}</ref> Japan <ref>{{cite web|title=Fujita Business Partners official website|url=http://fbps.jp|access-date=2018-11-19|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130730225055/http://fbps.jp/#|archive-date=2013-07-30|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> and the US,<ref>{{cite web|title=List of distributors|url=http://www.hi-vawt.com.tw/en/distributors.html}}</ref> which serve those individual regional markets.
==Products== Hi-VAWT’s services including [[vertical axis wind turbine]]s (ranges from 300 to 3000 watts system), [[solar panels]] and hybrid street lights system. The DS-3000 wind turbine system currently is the only vertical axis wind turbine system that has been certified by [[Nippon Kaiji Kyokai]] <ref>{{cite web|title=Register of wind turbine certification|url=http://www.classnk.or.jp/hp/pdf/activities/windmill_attestation/en/reg_wind_e.pdf}}</ref> and qualify for [[Feed-in tariff]] application in Japan and Taiwan.<ref>{{cite web|title=ROC launches small wind turbine certification|url=http://www.taiwantoday.tw/ct.asp?xItem=207876&ctNode=445}}</ref>

'''Jog''' describes the turns of a [[dislocation]] line inside a [[crystal structure]]. A [[dislocation]] line is rarely uniformly straight as in the figure, often containing many curves and/or steps to facilitate movement through the crystal in incremental amounts, rather than shifting the entire line at once. One of these step types is a jog, the other is a kink. However, both are typically referred to as jogs, which can be a source of confusion.
Segments of [[dislocation]] line that have a component of their sense vector normal to the glide plane are termed '''jogs'''.<ref>Hirth, Lothe, 1982</ref> See image for the definitions of the sense vector and the glide plane. Segments of dislocation line that do not leave the original glide plane are termed '''kinks'''.
Jogs are often very immobile compared to kinks, and require diffusion of crystallographic defects like vacancies or interstitial atoms to [[Dislocation#Dislocation_climb|climb]]. They are not capable of glide (movement in the [[glide plane]]) because the direction of motion is in the plane normal direction, not on the plane itself as with kinks. [[Image:Disloc coin.JPG|thumb|300px|Schematic representation of an [[edge dislocation]] in a crystal lattice. The yellow plane is the [[glide plane]], the [[Euclidean vector|vector]] '''u''' is the dislocation sense vector, '''b''' is the [[Burgers vector]]. When the dislocation moves from left to right through the crystal, the lower half of the crystal has moved one Burgers vector length to the left, relative to the upper half.]]
==Notes== <references /> Hirth, J. P., Lothe, J., Theory of Dislocations, 2nd edition, Krieger Publishing Company, Malabar, Florida, 1982 reprint 1992, page 261

The '''Kadowaki–Woods ratio''' is the ratio of ''A'', the quadratic term of the [[resistivity]] and ''γ''<sup>2</sup>, the linear term of the [[specific heat]]. This ratio is found to be a constant for [[transition metal]]s, and for heavy-[[fermion]] compounds, although at different values. :<math>R_\mathrm{KW} = \frac{A}{\gamma^2}</math>
In 1968 M. J. Rice pointed out <ref> {{cite journal |author=M. J. Rice |year=1968 |title=Electron-electron scattering in transition metals |journal=[[Phys. Rev. Lett.]] |volume=20 |issue=25 |pages=1439-1441 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.20.1439 |bibcode = 1968PhRvL..20.1439R }} </ref> that the coefficient ''A'' should vary predominantly as the square of the linear electronic specific heat coefficient γ; in particular he showed that the ratio ''A/γ''<sup>2</sup> is material independent for the pure 3d, 4d and 5d transition metals. Heavy-fermion compounds are characterized by very large values of A and γ. Kadowaki and Woods <ref> {{cite journal |author1=K. Kadowaki |author2=S.B. Woods |year=1986 |title=Universal relationship of the resistivity and specific heat in heavy-fermion compounds |journal=[[Solid State Communications]] |volume=58 |issue=8| pages=507–509 |doi=10.1016/0038-1098(86)90785-4 |bibcode = 1986SSCom..58..507K }} </ref> showed that ''A/γ''<sup>2</sup> is material-independent within the heavy-fermion compounds, and that it is about 25 times larger than in aforementioned transition metals.
According to the theory of electron-electron scattering <ref>{{cite journal |author=W. G. Baber |year=1937 |title=The contribution to the electrical resistance of metals from collisions between electrons |journal=[[Proc. Roy. Soc. A]] |volume= 158 |issue=894 |pages=383-396 |doi=10.1098/rspa.1937.0027 |bibcode = 1937RSPSA.158..383B }} </ref> <ref> {{cite book |author1=P. Nozières |author2=D. Pines |title=The Theory of Quantum Liquids, Vol. 1 |publisher=Benjamin |place=New York |year=1966 }} </ref> <ref> {{cite journal |author1=W. E. Lawrence |author2=J. W. Wilkins |year=1973 |title=Electron-electron scattering in the transport coefficients of simple metals |journal=[[Phys. Rev. B]] |volume= 7|issue=6 |pages=2317 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevB.7.2317 |bibcode = 1973PhRvB...7.2317L }} </ref> the ratio ''A/γ''<sup>2</sup> contains indeed several non-universal factors, including the square of the strength of the effective electron-electron interaction. Since in general the interactions differ in nature from one group of materials to another, the same values of ''A/γ''<sup>2</sup> are only expected within a particular group. In 2005 Hussey<ref>{{cite journal |author=N. E. Hussey |year=2005 |title=Non-generality of the Kadowaki-Woods ratio in correlated oxides |journal=[[J. Phys. Soc. Jpn.]] |volume=74 |issue=4 |pages=1107-1110 |doi=10.1143/JPSJ.74.1107 |arxiv = cond-mat/0409252 |bibcode = 2005JPSJ...74.1107H }} </ref> proposed a re-scaling of ''A/γ''<sup>2</sup> to account for unit cell volume, dimensionality, carrier density and multi-band effects. In 2009 Jacko, Fjaerestad, and Powell<ref>{{cite journal |author1=A.C. Jacko |author2=J.O. Fjaerestad |author3=B.J. Powell |year=2009 |title=A unified explanation of the Kadowaki–Woods ratio in strongly correlated metals |journal=[[Nature Physics]] |volume=5 |pages=422–425 |doi=10.1038/nphys1249 |arxiv=0805.4275 |issue=6 |bibcode = 2009NatPh...5..422J }} </ref> demonstrated ''f''<sub>dx</sub>''(n)A/γ''<sup>2</sup> to have the same value in transition metals, heavy fermions, organics and oxides with ''A'' varying over 10 orders of magnitude, where ''f''<sub>dx</sub>''(n)'' may be written in terms of the dimensionality of the system, the electron density and, in layered systems, the interlayer spacing or the interlayer hopping integral.

revision.text:
'''Microrheology'''<ref> {{cite journal |author=Mason, Thomas G.|author2=Weitz, David A. |last-author-amp=yes |date=1995 |title=Optical Measurements of Frequency-Dependent Linear Viscoelastic Moduli of Complex Fluids |journal=[[Physical Review Letters]] |volume=74 |pages=7 |doi=10.1103/physrevlett.74.1250 |bibcode = 1995PhRvL..74.1250M |pmid=10058972}}</ref> is a technique used to measure the [[rheology|rheological properties]] of a medium, such as [[microviscosity]], via the measurement of the trajectory of a [[flow tracer]] (a [[micrometre]]-sized particle). It is a new way of doing [[rheology]], traditionally done using a [[rheometer]]. There are two types of microrheology: ''passive microrheology'' and ''active microrheology''. Passive microrheology uses inherent [[thermal energy]] to move the tracers, whereas active microrheology uses externally applied forces, such as from a [[magnetic field]] or an [[optical tweezer]], to do so. Microrheology can be further differentiated into 1- and 2-particle methods.<ref name="Crocker2000"> {{cite journal |author=Crocker, John C. |display-authors=4 |author2=Valentine, M. T. |author3=Weeks, Eric R. |author4=Gisler, T. |author5=Kaplan, P. D. |author6=Yodh, A. G. |author7=Weitz, D. A. |last-author-amp=yes |date=2000 |title=Two-Point Microrheology of Inhomogeneous Soft Materials |journal=[[Physical Review Letters]] |volume=85 |pages=888–891 |doi= 10.1103/PhysRevLett.85.888 |issue=4 |bibcode = 2000PhRvL..85..888C |pmid=10991424}}</ref> <ref name="Levine2000"> {{cite journal |author=Levine, Alex J. |author2=Lubensky, T. C. |last-author-amp=yes |date=2000 |title=One- and Two-Particle Microrheology |journal=[[Physical Review Letters]] |volume=85 |pages=1774–1777 |doi= 10.1103/PhysRevLett.85.1774 |issue=8 |arxiv = cond-mat/0004103 |bibcode = 2000PhRvL..85.1774L }}</ref>
== Passive microrheology==
'' Passive microrheology '' uses the thermal energy (''kT'') to move the tracers, although recent evidence suggests that active random forces inside cells may instead move the tracers in a diffusive-like manner.<ref Name = "Guo"/> The trajectories of the tracers are measured optically either by microscopy or by [[diffusing-wave spectroscopy]] (DWS). From the [[mean squared displacement]] with respect to time (noted MSD or <Δ''r''<sup>2</sup>> ), one can calculate the visco-elastic moduli ''G''′(''ω'') and ''G''″(''ω'') using the [[Einstein relation (kinetic theory)|generalized Stokes–Einstein relation]] (GSER). Here is a view of the trajectory of a particle of micrometer size.
<gallery> Image:Brownian_trajectory.png|Typical trajectory of a Brownian particle (simulation) Image:examples_MSD_pure_viscous_and_elastic.png|Two examples of MSD: one for a purely viscous fluid (free diffusion) and one for a viscolelastic fluid (trapped by elastic network) Image:Film particule ds polymere.gif|Animation of a particle in a polymer-like network </gallery>
In a standard passive microrheology test, the movement of dozens of tracers is tracked in a single video frame. The motivation is to average the movements of the tracers and calculate a robust MSD profile.
Observing the MSD for a wide range of integration time scales (or frequencies) gives information on the microstructure of the medium where are diffusing the tracers.
If the tracers are having a free diffusion in a purely viscous material, the MSD should grows linearly with sampling integration time:
<math>< \Delta r^2>=4Dt</math>.
If the tracers are moving in a spring-like fashion within a purely elastic material, the MSD should have no time dependence:
<math>< \Delta r^2>=Const</math>
In most cases the tracers are presenting a sub-linear integration-time dependence, indicating the medium has intermediate viscoelastic properties. Of course, the slope changes in different time scales, as the nature of the response from the material is frequency dependent.
Microrheology is another way to do linear rheology. Since the force involved is very weak (order of 10<sup>−15</sup> N), microrheology is guaranteed to be in the so-called linear region of the strain/stress relationship. It is also able to measure very small volumes (biological cell).
Given the complex viscoelastic modulus <math>G(\omega)=G'(\omega)+i G''(\omega)\,</math> with ''G''′(''ω'') the elastic (conservative) part and ''G''″(''ω'') the viscous (dissipative) part and ''ω''=2''πf'' the pulsation. The GSER is as follows: :<math>\tilde{G}(s)=\frac{k_{\mathrm{B}}T}{\pi a s \langle\Delta \tilde{r}^{2}(s)\rangle}</math>
with :<math>\tilde{G}(s)</math>: [[Laplace]] transform of ''G'' :''k''<sub>B</sub>: [[Boltzmann]] constant :''T'': temperature in kelvins :''s'': the Laplace frequency :''a'': the radius of the tracer :<math>\langle\Delta \tilde{r}^{2}(s)\rangle</math>: the Laplace transform of the mean squared displacement
A related method of passive microrheology involves the tracking positions of a particle at high frequency, often with a quadrant photodiode.<ref name="Schnurr1997"> {{cite journal |author=Schnurr, B. |author2=Gittes, F. |author3=MacKintosh, F. C. |author4=Schmidt, C. F. |last-author-amp=yes |date=1997 |title=Determining Microscopic Viscoelasticity in Flexible and Semiflexible Polymer Networks from Thermal Fluctuations |journal=Macromolecules |volume=30 |pages=7781–7792 |doi= 10.1021/ma970555n |issue=25 |arxiv = cond-mat/9709231 |bibcode = 1997MaMol..30.7781S }}</ref> From the position, <math>x(t)</math>, the power spectrum, <math><x_{\omega}^2></math> can be found, and then related to the real and imaginary parts of the response function, <math>\alpha(\omega)</math>.<ref name="Gittes1997"> {{cite journal |author=Gittes, F. |display-authors=4 |author2=Schnurr, B. |author3=Olmsted, P. D. |author4=MacKintosh, F. C. |author5=Schmidt, C. F. |last-author-amp=yes |date=1997 |title=Determining Microscopic Viscoelasticity in Flexible and Semiflexible Polymer Networks from Thermal Fluctuations |journal=[[Physical Review Letters]] |volume=79 |pages=3286–3289 |doi= 10.1103/PhysRevLett.79.3286 |issue=17 |arxiv = cond-mat/9709228 |bibcode = 1997PhRvL..79.3286G }}</ref> The response function leads directly to a calculation of the complex shear modulus, <math>G(\omega)</math> via: :<math>G(\omega) = \frac{1}{6 \pi a \alpha(\omega)}</math> : :
== Two Point Microrheology<ref name=":0" /> ==
There could be many artifacts that change the values measured by the passive microrheology tests, resulting in a disagreement between microrheology and normal [[rheology]]. These artifacts include tracer-matrix interactions, tracer-matrix size mismatch and more.
A different microrheological approach studies the [[cross-correlation]] of two tracers in the same sample. In practice, instead of measuring the MSD - <math>< \Delta r^2></math>, movements of two distinct particles are measured - <math>< \Delta r_1 \Delta r_2></math>. Calculating the G(ω) of the medium between the tracers follows:
<math>\tilde{G}(s)=\frac{k_{\mathrm{B}}T}{2\pi R s \langle\Delta \tilde{r}_1(s)\Delta \tilde{r}_2(s)\rangle}</math>
Notice this equation does not depend on '''a''', but instead in depends on '''R''' - the distance between the tracers (assuming R>>a).
Some studies has shown that this method is better in coming to agreement with standard rheological measurements (in the relevant frequencies and materials)
== Active microrheology ==
''Active microrheology'' may use a [[magnetic field]] ,<ref>{{cite journal |author=A.R. Bausch |display-authors=etal |date=1999 |title=Measurement of local viscoelasticity and forces in living cells by magnetic tweezers|journal=[[Biophysical Journal]] |volume=76 |pages=573–9 |doi=10.1016/S0006-3495(99)77225-5 |pmid=9876170 |bibcode=1999BpJ....76..573B |issue=1 Pt 1 |pmc=1302547 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=K.S. Zaner |author2=P.A. Valberg |last-author-amp=yes |date=1989 |title=Viscoelasticity of F-actin measured with magnetic microparticles|journal=[[Journal of Cell Biology]] |volume=109 |pages=2233–43 |doi=10.1083/jcb.109.5.2233 |pmid=2808527 |issue=5 |pmc=2115855 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=F.Ziemann |author2=J. Radler |author3=E. Sackmann |last-author-amp=yes |date=1994 |title=Local measurements of viscoelastic moduli of entangled actin networks using an oscillating magnetic bead micro-rheometer|journal=[[Biophysical Journal]] |volume=66 |pages=2210–6 |doi=10.1016/S0006-3495(94)81017-3 |pmid=8075354 |bibcode=1994BpJ....66.2210Z |issue=6 |pmc=1275947 }}</ref><ref name=":0">{{cite journal|first=John C. Crocker|last-author-amp=yes|date=2000|title=Two-Point Microrheology of Inhomogeneous Soft Materials|url=https://journals.aps.org/prl/abstract/10.1103/PhysRevLett.85.888|journal=Phys. Rev. Lett.|volume=85|pages=888–891|via=|author=Weitz, D. A.|bibcode=2000PhRvL..85..888C|doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.85.888}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=F. Amblard |display-authors=etal |date=1996 |title=Subdiffusion and Anomalous Local Viscoelasticity in Actin Networks|journal=[[Physical Review Letters]] |volume=77 |pages=4470–4473 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.77.4470 |pmid=10062546 |bibcode=1996PhRvL..77.4470A |issue=21 }}</ref> <ref>{{cite journal |author=Manlio Tassieri |display-authors=etal |date=2010 |title=Analysis of the linear viscoelasticity of polyelectrolytes by magnetic microrheometry—Pulsed creep experiments and the one particle response |journal=[[Journal of Rheology]] |volume=54 |pages=117-131 |doi=10.1122/1.3266946|bibcode=2010JRheo..54..117T }}</ref> [[optical tweezers]]<ref>{{cite journal |author=E. Helfer |display-authors=etal |date=2000 |title=Microrheology of Biopolymer-Membrane Complexes|journal=[[Physical Review Letters]] |volume=85 |pages=457–60 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.85.457 |pmid=10991307 |bibcode=2000PhRvL..85..457H |issue=2 }}</ref> <ref>{{cite journal |author=Manlio Tassieri |display-authors=etal |date=2009 |title=Measuring storage and loss moduli using optical tweezers: Broadband microrheology |journal=[[Phys. Rev. E]] |volume=81 |pages=026308 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevE.81.026308|arxiv=0910.1339 |bibcode=2010PhRvE..81b6308T }}</ref> <ref>{{cite journal |author=Daryl Preece |display-authors=etal |date=2011 |title=Optical tweezers: wideband microrheology |journal=[[Journal of Optics (IOP Publishing journal)|Journal of Optics]] |volume=13 |pages= 044022 |doi=10.1088/2040-8978/13/4/044022 |issue=11|arxiv=1005.1401 |bibcode=2011JOpt...13d4022P }}</ref> <ref>{{cite journal |author=Manlio Tassieri |display-authors=etal |date=2012 |title=Microrheology with optical tweezers: data analysis|journal=[[New Journal of Physics]] |volume=14 |pages=115032 |doi=10.1088/1367-2630/14/11/115032 |issue=11 |bibcode = 2012NJPh...14k5032T }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|first=|last-author-amp=yes|date=2012|title=Unconventional structure-assisted optical manipulation of high-index nanowires in liquid crystals|url=|journal=[[Optics Express]]|volume=20|issue=7|pages=7741–7748|bibcode=2012OExpr..20.7741E|doi=10.1364/OE.20.007741|via=|author=David Engström|display-authors=4|author2=Michael C.M. Varney|author3=Martin Persson|author4=Rahul P. Trivedi|author5=Kris A. Bertness|author6=Mattias Goksör|author7=Ivan I. Smalyukh}}</ref> and [[Atomic-force microscopy|Atomic force microscope]]<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Rigato|first=Annafrancesca|last2=Miyagi|first2=Atsushi|last3=Scheuring|first3=Simon|last4=Rico|first4=Felix|date=2017-05-01|title=High-frequency microrheology reveals cytoskeleton dynamics in living cells|url=https://www.nature.com/nphys/journal/vaop/ncurrent/full/nphys4104.html|journal=Nature Physics|language=en|volume=advance online publication|doi=10.1038/nphys4104|issn=1745-2481|bibcode=2017NatPh..13..771R}}</ref> to apply a force on the tracer and then find the stress/strain relation.
The force applied is a sinusoidal force with amplitude A and frequency ω -
<math>F=A sin(\omega t)</math>
The response of the tracer is a factor of the matrix visco-elastic nature. If a matrix is totally elastic (a solid), the response to the acting force should be immediate and the tracers should be observed moving by-
<math>X_e=B sin(\omega t)</math>.
with <math>A/B = G(\omega)</math>.
On the other hand, if the matrix is totally viscous (a liquid), there should be a phase shift of <math>90^o</math> between the strain and the stress -
<math>X_v=B sin(\omega t + 90^o) = Bcos(\omega t)</math>
in reality, as most materials are visco-elastic, the phase shift observed is <math>0<\varphi<90</math>.
When φ>45 the matrix is considered mostly in its "viscous domain" and when φ<45 the matrix is considered mostly in its "elastic domain".
Given a measured response phase shift φ (sometimes noted as δ), this ratio applies:
<math>\frac{G''}{G'}=\frac{\frac{A}{B}sin(\varphi)}{\frac{A}{B}cos(\varphi)}=tan(\varphi)</math>
Similar response phase analysis is used in regular [[rheology]] testing.
More recently, it has been developed into [[Force spectrum microscopy]] to measure contributions of random active motor proteins to diffusive motion in the [[cytoskeleton]].<ref name="Guo">{{cite journal|title=Probing the Stochastic, Motor-Driven Properties of the Cytoplasm Using Force Spectrum Microscopy|last1=Guo|first1=Ming|display-authors=etal|journal=Cell|date=2014|volume=158 |pages=822–832|doi=10.1016/j.cell.2014.06.051|pmid=25126787|pmc=4183065}}</ref>

{{Infobox newspaper | name = Oil & Gas Journal | logo = | image = | caption = | type = Weekly | format = | owners = [[PennWell Corporation]] | founder = | publisher = Jim Klingele | editor = Bob Tippee | chiefeditor = | assoceditor = | maneditor = | newseditor = | managingeditordesign = | opeditor = | photoeditor = | staff = | foundation = {{Start date and age|1902}} | political = | language = English | ceased publication = | headquarters = [[Tulsa, Oklahoma]] | circulation = | sister newspapers = ''Offshore Magazine'' | ISSN = 0030-1388 | oclc = 2390105 | website = {{url|www.ogj.com}} }} The '''''Oil & Gas Journal''''' is a leading [[petroleum industry]] weekly publication with a worldwide coverage. It is headquartered in [[Tulsa, Oklahoma]] and the journal has a major presence in [[Houston, Texas]]. The journal is published by [[PennWell Corporation]].<ref name=lexisnexis/> Its publisher is Paul Westervelt, Vice President of PennWell Corporation, and editor is Bob Tippee.<ref name=pubexec> {{cite news | last = Sabatier | first = Lou Ann | title = Everything Publishing. An Interview with Paul Westervelt, VP and Group Publishing Director, Oil & Gas Journal, PennWell | work = Publishing Executive | date = 2011-01-12 | url =http://www.pubexec.com/blog/paul-westervelt-pennwells-oil-gas-journal-paid-content-trade | accessdate = 2011-11-12 }}</ref><ref name=bbc> {{cite news | last = Moylan | first = John | title = Oil drilling returns to Gulf of Mexico | work = [[BBC News]] | date = 2011-11-09 | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-15634485 | accessdate = 2011-11-12 }}</ref> The first issue was published in 1902.<ref name=houston> {{cite news | last = Perin | first = Monica | title = Wageneck named publisher of Oil & Gas Journal | newspaper = [[Houston Business Journal]] | date = 2011-11-09 | url = http://www.bizjournals.com/houston/stories/2006/05/29/daily4.html?jst=b_ln_hl | accessdate = 2011-11-12 }}</ref> Its online information services started in 1994.<ref name=pubexec/>
[[LexisNexis]] database describes the ''Oil & Gas Journal'' as an authoritative source on the petroleum industry aimed at engineers, oil management and executives throughout the oil and gas industry.<ref name=lexisnexis> {{cite web | title = Source Information: Oil and Gas Journal | publisher = [[LexisNexis]] | url = http://w3.nexis.com/sources/scripts/info.pl?8039 | accessdate=2011-11-12 }}</ref> The weekly publishes news, analysis, statistics, and technology updates on exploration, drilling, production, pipeline, transportation, refining, processing and marketing.<ref name=lexisnexis/> It is a subscription trade publication. ''Oil & Gas Journal'' has about 20,000 subscribers for the printed issue and 80,000 for digital subscriptions.<ref name=pubexec/>
The ''Oil & Gas Journal'' began in 1902 as the ''Oil Investor's Journal'' of [[Beaumont, Texas]], which covered the oil boom that followed the nearby [[Spindletop]] discovery. As the oil discoveries spread along the Gulf Coast, the magazine relocated to Houston. In 1910 the magazine was purchased by Patrick C. Boyle, long-time publisher of the ''Oil City Derrick'' in Pennsylvania. Boyle moved the publication briefly to [[St. Louis, Missouri]], then to Tulsa, where it still resides.<ref>"Patrick C. Boyle," ''Oil Trade Journal'', May 1920, p.92.</ref>

| spacecraft_bus = | manufacturer = | dry_mass = | launch_mass = {{convert|80000|kg|lb}} | dimensions = 37 m × 4.10 m | power =
| launch_date = {{start-date|15 May 1987}} | launch_rocket = [[Energia]] | launch_site = [[Baikonur Cosmodrome|Baikonur]] [[Baikonur Cosmodrome Site 250|250]] | launch_contractor =
| orbit_epoch = Planned | orbit_reference = [[geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[low Earth orbit|Low Earth]] | orbit_periapsis = | orbit_apoapsis = | orbit_inclination = | orbit_period = | apsis = gee }}
[[File:Energia-Polyus drawing.png|thumbnail|upright=0.5|left|Polyus satellite on Energia launch vehicle.]]
The '''Polyus''' spacecraft ({{lang-ru|'''Полюс'''}}, ''[[geographical pole|pole]]''), also known as '''Polus''', '''Skif-DM''', [[GRAU]] index '''17F19DM''', was a prototype [[space weapon|orbital weapons platform]] designed to destroy [[Strategic Defense Initiative]] satellites with a megawatt [[Carbon dioxide laser|carbon-dioxide laser]].<ref name=starwars>{{cite web| url = http://www.buran.ru/htm/str163.htm| title = "Звёздные войны, которых не было" (''Star Wars'' that didn't happen)| author = Konstantin Lantratov}}</ref> It had a [[Functional Cargo Block]] derived from a [[TKS spacecraft]] to control its orbit and it could fire test targets to demonstrate the fire control system.
The Polyus spacecraft was launched 15 May 1987 from [[Baikonur Cosmodrome]] [[Baikonur Cosmodrome Site 250|Site 250]] as part of the first flight of the [[Energia]] system,<ref>{{cite book|author1=Bart Hendrickx|author2=Bert Vis|title=Energiya-Buran: The Soviet Space Shuttle|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VRb1yAGVWNsC|year=2007|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|isbn=978-0-387-73984-7}}</ref> but failed to reach orbit.
According to [[Yuri Kornilov]], Chief Designer of the Salyut Design Bureau, shortly before Polyus' launch, [[Mikhail Gorbachev]] visited the Baikonur Cosmodrome and expressly forbade the in-orbit testing of its capabilities. Kornilov claims that Gorbachev was worried that it would be possible for Western governments to view this activity as an attempt to create a weapon in space and that such an attempt would contradict the country's previous statements on the USSR’s peaceful intent.<ref name=kornilov>{{cite journal| title = Unknown Polyus| author = Yuri Kornilov| journal = Earth and the Universe}}</ref>
For technical reasons, the payload was launched upside down. It was designed to separate from the Energia, rotate 180 degrees in yaw, then 90 degrees in roll and then fire its engine to complete its boost to orbit. The Energia functioned perfectly. However, after separation from Energia, the Polyus spun a full 360 degrees instead of the planned 180 degrees. When the engine fired, it slowed and burned up in the atmosphere over the south Pacific Ocean. This failure was attributed to a faulty [[inertial guidance system]] that had not been rigorously tested due to the rushed production schedule.<ref name=grondine>{{cite web |url = http://www.astronautix.com/craft/polyus.htm |title = Polyus |author = Ed Grondine |accessdate = 2009-09-15 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100102201428/http://astronautix.com/craft/polyus.htm |archivedate = 2010-01-02 }}</ref>
Parts of the Polyus project's hardware were re-used in [[Kvant-2]], [[Kristall]], [[Spektr]] and [[Priroda]] [[Mir]] modules, as well as in the [[ISS]] module [[Zarya]].
==Development== NPO ''Energia'' received orders from the [[Government of the Soviet Union|Soviet government]] to begin research on space-based strike weapons in the mid-70s. Even before, the USSR had been developing maneuverable satellites for the purpose of satellite interception. By the beginning of the 1980s, ''Energia'' had proposed two programs: laser-equipped ''Skif'' and guided missiles platform ''Kaskad'' (where ''Skif'' would cover the low-orbit targets, ''Kaskad'' engaged targets in high and geosynchronous orbits). Together with NPO ''Astrofizika'' and KB ''Salyut'', they began developing their orbital weapons platform based on the [[Salyut program|Salyut]] DOS-17K frame.
Later, when the objective of ICBM interception proved too difficult, the aims of the project were shifted towards anti-satellite weapons. The 1983 announcement by the US of their SDI program prompted further political and financial support for the satellite interceptor program. In the nuclear exchange scenario, the interceptors would destroy the SDI satellites, followed by a so-called "pre-emptive retaliation" large-scale Soviet ICBM launch.
The laser chosen for the ''Skif'' spacecraft was the 1-megawatt [[carbon dioxide laser]], developed for the [[Beriev A-60]] aircraft (an Il-76 flying laboratory with a combat laser). The introduction of the ''Energia'', capable of launching about 95 tonnes into orbit, finally allowed the spacecraft to accommodate the massive laser. The massive exhaust of the carbon-dioxide laser precipitated the objective of making the laser "recoil-less". The ''zero-torque exhaust system'' (SBM) was developed to that end. Its testing in orbit meant the release of a large cloud of carbon dioxide, which would hint at the satellite's purpose. Instead, the xenon-krypton mix would be used to simultaneously test the SBM and perform an innocent experiment on Earth's [[ionosphere]].
In 1985, the decision was made to test-launch the new ''Energia'' launch vehicle, which was still in the [[testbed]] phase. A 100-ton dummy payload was initially considered for the launch, but in a series of last-minute changes, it was decided that the almost-completed ''Skif'' spacecraft would be launched instead for a 30-day mission.
The development of the real ''Skif'' was completed in just one year, from September 1985 to September 1986. Testing and tweaking the ''Energia'' launch vehicle, the launch pad and the ''Skif'' itself moved the launch to February, and later to May 1987. According to Boris Gubanov, the head designer of the ''Energia'' launch vehicle, the work schedule of the preceding years was exhausting, and at the point of Mikhail Gorbachev's visit on 11 May, he asked the Soviet premier to clear the launch now, because "there will be heart attacks".
The catastrophic malfunction that led to ''Skif'' entering the atmosphere in the same area as ''Energia's'' second stage was successfully investigated. It was found that 568 seconds after launch, the timing control device gave the logical block a command to discard the side modules' covers and laser exhaust covers. Unknowingly, the same command was earlier used to open the solar panels and disengage the maneuvering thrusters. This wasn't discovered because of the logistics of the testing process and overall haste. Main thrusters engaged while the ''Skif'' kept turning, overshooting the intended 180-degree turn. The spacecraft lost speed and reverted to the [[ballistic trajectory]].

[[File:Quietrevolution wind turbine at the London Olympic Stadium.jpg|thumb|quietrevolution turbine at the [[London Olympic Stadium]]]] The '''quietrevolution''' is a discontinued brand of [[vertical-axis wind turbine]]. The helical design is most similar to the [[Gorlov helical turbine]]. Both are an evolution of the [[Darrieus wind turbine]]. It has won several awards including the "Sustainable Innovation Award" in 2006.
The turbine consists of three vertical [[airfoil]] blades, each having a [[Helix|helical]] twist of 120 degrees. This feature spreads the [[torque]] evenly over the entire revolution, thus preventing the destructive pulsations of the straight-bladed giromill (Darrieus turbine). The wind pushes each blade around on both the windward and [[leeward]] sides of the turbine.
The qr5 turbine, rated for 6 kW, measures 3.0m in diameter by 5m high.
Poor performance of a QR5 installed at Welsh government offices in [[Aberystwyth]] has been blamed on poor siting.<ref >{{Cite news |title=Welsh government's £48k wind turbine creates £5 of power a month |author=Paul Martin |date=7 November 2013 |newspaper=[[BBC News online]] |quote=A wind turbine that cost the Welsh government £48,000 to buy has been generating an average of just £5 worth of electricity per month. |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-24844182 }}</ref> The turbine's overall cost was given as £48,000 and in 2012 it generated an average of 33 [[kWh]] per month, a value of £5.28 per month.

'''Radiophysics''' (also modern writing "Radio Physics"<ref>Official web-page of the [http://www.radiophysicssolutions.com/ "Radio Physics Solutions" company] founded recently in United Kingdom</ref>) is a branch of [[physics]] focused on the theoretical and experimental study of certain kinds of [[radiation]]: its emission, propagation, and interaction with matter.
The term is used in the following major meanings: *study of [[radio wave]]s (the original area of research) *study of radiation used in [[radiology]]<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20120205102047/http://www.medcyclopaedia.com/library/radiology/chapter03.aspx?s=radiophysics&mode=1&syn=&scope= "Radiophysics" article] in ''Medcyclopaedia'' (archived from the original), online version of the ''[[Encyclopaedia of Medical Imaging]]''</ref> *study of other ranges of the spectrum of [[electromagnetic radiation]] in some specific applications
Among the main applications of radiophysics are [[radio]] communications, [[radiolocation]], [[radio astronomy]], and radiology.
==Branches== *Classical radiophysics deals with radio wave communications and detection *[[Quantum radiophysics]] (physics of [[laser]]s and [[maser]]s; [[Nikolai Basov]] was the founder of quantum radiophysics in the [[Soviet Union]]) *[[Statistical radiophysics]]
==See also== *[[University of Kiev Faculty of Radio Physics, Electronics and Computer Systems|University of Kyiv Faculty of Radio Physics, Electronics and Computer Systems]] *[[Institute of Radio-engineering and Electronics]] *[[Institute for Physical Research]] *[[University of Calcutta]] *[[Australian Academy of Science]] *[[Tomsk State University]] *[[Yerevan State University]] *[[N.
