{{redirect|Railway sleeper|passenger cars with beds|sleeping car}}
[[File:Railroad tieswoodconcrete.jpg|thumb|Wooden ties are used on many traditional railways. In the background is a track with concrete ties.]]
A '''railroad tie'''/'''railway tie'''/'''crosstie''' ([[North America]]) or '''railway sleeper''' ([[Great Britain|Britain]], [[Ireland]], [[South Asia]], [[Australasia]], and [[Africa]]) is a rectangular support for the [[Track (rail transport)|rails]] in [[railroad tracks]]. Generally laid perpendicular to the rails, ties transfer loads to the [[track ballast]] and [[subgrade]], hold the rails upright and keep them spaced to the correct [[rail gauge|gauge]].
Railroad ties are traditionally made of [[wood]], but [[pre-stressed concrete]] is now also widely used, especially in Europe and Asia. [[Steel]] ties are common on secondary lines in the UK;<ref>{{cite web|title=Steel Sleepers in the Rail Industry – they are still made, and have quite a history|url=https://shop.bsigroup.com/Navigate-by/Membership/Benefits-and-services/BSI-Knowledge-Centre/Withdrawn-standards/Steel-Sleepers-in-the-Rail-Industry-they-are-still-made-and-have-quite-a-history/|accessdate=August 9, 2017}}</ref> [[Composite lumber|plastic composite]] ties are also employed, although far less than wood or concrete. As of January 2008, the approximate market share in North America for traditional and wood ties was 91.5%, the remainder being concrete, steel, [[Lophira alata|azobé]] (red ironwood) and plastic composite.<ref>{{cite journal|title=M/W Budgets To Climb in 2008|journal=Railway Track & Structures|url=http://www.nxtbook.com/nxtbooks/sb/rts0108/index.php|accessdate=23 December 2011|date=January 2008|pages=18–25|issn=0033-9016|oclc=1763403|volume=104|issue=1|publisher=Simmons-Boardman Publishing Company|location=New York, New York}}</ref>
Approximately 3,520 wooden crossties are used per mile of mainline railroad track in the US (distance between ties is [[Real versus nominal value#Measurement|nominally]] {{convert|18|in|cm|0|abbr=on}} including one tie and the crib), {{convert|3520|/mi|/km}} <!-- See [[Talk:Railroad tie#Arithmetic]] --> (40 per {{convert|60|ft|m|1|abbr=on|disp=or}} rail) on main lines in the UK. Rails in the US may be fastened to the tie by a [[railroad spike]]; iron/steel [[Rail fastening systems#Rail supports|baseplates]] screwed to the tie and secured to the rail by a proprietary fastening system such as a [[Vossloh]] or [[Pandrol]] are commonly used in Europe.
==Types==
===Stone block=== [[File:Kilmarnock & Troon railway sleeper.JPG|thumb|Stone block from the [[Kilmarnock and Troon Railway]]]] The type of railroad tie used on the predecessors of the first true railway ([[Liverpool and Manchester Railway]]) consisted of a pair of stone blocks laid into the ground, with the chairs holding the rails fixed to those blocks. One advantage of this method of construction was that it allowed horses to tread the middle path without the risk of tripping. In railway use with ever heavier locomotives, it was found that it was hard to maintain the correct [[Rail gauge|gauge]]. The stone blocks were in any case unsuitable on soft ground, such as at [[Chat Moss]], where timber ties had to be used. [[Railroad tie#Bi-block ties|Bi-block]] ties with a tie rod are somewhat similar.
===Wooden=== [[File:Geschweisster schienenstoss.jpeg|thumb|A variant fastening of rails to wooden ties]] Historically wooden rail ties were made by hewing with an axe, called [[axe ties]] or sawn to achieve at least two flat sides. A variety of [[softwood]] and [[hardwood]]s timbers are used as ties, [[oak]], [[jarrah]] and [[karri]] being popular hardwoods, although increasingly difficult to obtain, especially from sustainable sources.<ref name="hay437-438">Hay 1982, pp. 437–438</ref> Some lines use [[softwood]]s, including [[Douglas fir]]; while they have the advantage of accepting [[wood preservative|treatment]] more readily, they are more susceptible to wear but are cheaper, lighter (and therefore easier to handle) and more readily available.<ref name="hay437-438"/> Softwood is treated, while [[creosote]] is the most common preservative for railway ties, preservatives are also sometimes used such as [[pentachlorophenol]], [[chromated copper arsenate]] and a few other preservatives. Sometimes non-toxic preservatives are used, such as [[copper]] [[azole]] or micronized [[copper]]. New [[boron]]-based wood preserving technology is being employed by major US railroads in a dual treatment process in order to extend the life of wood ties in wet areas.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=Crossties|date=March–April 2010|issn=0097-4536|oclc=1565511|publisher=Railway Tie Association|location=Paterson, New Jersey}}</ref> Some timbers (such as [[Shorea robusta|sal]], [[Mora (plant)|mora]], [[jarrah]] or [[azobé]]) are durable enough that they can be used untreated.<ref>Flint & Richards 1992, p. 92</ref>
Problems with wooden ties include rot, splitting, insect infestation, plate-cutting, also known as chair shuffle in the UK (abrasive damage to the tie caused by lateral motion of the tie plate) and spike-pull (where the spike is gradually loosened from the tie). For more information on wooden ties the [[Railway Tie Association]] maintains a comprehensive website devoted to wood tie research and statistics.
Wooden ties can, of course, catch fire; as they age they develop cracks that allow sparks to lodge so that they catch fire more easily.
===Concrete=== {{main|Concrete sleeper}} [[File:Concrete sleeper 1638.JPG|right|thumb|Concrete ties on the [[BNSF]] line north of [[Yakima, Washington]]]] Concrete ties are cheaper and easier to obtain than timber{{dubious|date=December 2016}} and better able to carry higher axle-weights and sustain higher speeds. Their greater weight ensures improved retention of [[track geometry]], especially when installed with continuous-welded rail. Concrete ties have a longer service life and require less maintenance than timber due to their greater weight, which helps them remain in the correct position longer. Concrete ties need to be installed on a well-prepared subgrade with an adequate depth on free-draining ballast to perform well. Concrete ties amplify wheel noise, so wooden ties are often used in densely populated areas.
On the highest categories of line in the UK (those with the highest speeds and tonnages), pre-stressed concrete ties are the only ones permitted by [[Network Rail]] standards.
Most European railways also now use concrete bearers in switches and crossing layouts due to the longer life and lower cost of concrete bearers compared to timber, which is increasingly difficult and expensive to source in sufficient quantities and quality.
===Steel=== [[File:Pine Creek Rail Steel Sleepers DSC03637.jpg|thumb|Steel ties]] Steel ties are formed from pressed steel and are trough-shaped in section. The ends of the tie are shaped to form a "spade" which increases the lateral resistance of the tie. Housings to accommodate the fastening system are welded to the upper surface of the tie. Steel ties are now in widespread use on secondary or lower-speed lines in the UK where they have been found to be economical to install due their ability to be installed on the existing ballast bed. Steel ties are lighter in weight than concrete and able to stack in compact bundles unlike timber. Steel ties can be installed onto the existing ballast, unlike concrete ties which require a full depth of new ballast. Steel ties are 100% recyclable and require up to 60% less ballast than concrete ties and up to 45% less than wood ties.
Historically, steel ties have suffered from poor design and increased traffic loads over their normally long service life. These aged and often obsolete designs limited load and speed capacity but can still be found in many locations globally and performing adequately despite decades of service. There are great numbers of steel ties with over 50 years of service and in some cases they can and have been rehabilitated and continue to perform well. Steel ties were also used in specialty situations, such as the [[Hejaz Railway]] in the [[Arabian Peninsula]], which had an ongoing problem with [[Bedouin]]s who would steal wooden ties for campfires.<ref>{{cite journal|title=The Hedjaz Railroad|journal=[[The Railroad Gazette]]|volume=42|issue=23|page=800|date=7 June 1907|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-I1MAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA800&lpg=PA800&dq=hejaz+railway+wooden+ties+fires&source=bl&ots=WzB0XcSSiE&sig=aGhHDJyc4lS72VQDTxgT1SvUWQk&hl=en&ei=9iL2Tf2CBMeugQf-9LHsCw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAw#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=23 December 2011|issn=0097-6679|oclc=15110419}}</ref>
Modern steel ties handle heavy loads, have a proven record of performance in signalized track, and handle adverse track conditions. Of high importance to railroad companies is the fact that steel ties are more economical to install in new construction than creosote-treated wood ties and concrete ties. Steel ties are utilized in nearly all sectors of the worldwide railroad systems including heavy-haul, class 1s, regional, shortlines, mining, electrified passenger lines (OHLE) and all manner of industries. Notably, steel ties (bearers) have proven themselves over the last few decades to be advantageous in turnouts (switches/points) and provide the solution to the ever-growing problem of long timber ties for such use.
When insulated to prevent conduction through the ties, steel ties may be used with [[track circuit]] based train detection and track integrity systems. Without insulation, steel ties may only be used on lines without block signaling and [[level crossings]] or on lines that use other forms of train detection such as [[axle counter]]s.
===Plastics=== [[File:KLP Hybrid Plastic Sleeper.JPG|thumb|KLP Hybrid Plastic Railroad Tie]] [[File:Tie placer.JPG|thumb|Tie placer in [[Hyannis, Massachusetts]]]]
In more recent times, a number of companies are selling composite railroad ties manufactured from [[plastic recycling#Applications|recycled plastic]] resins<ref>{{cite web|title=Polywood Composite Railroad Ties Facts|url=http://www.polywood.com/plastic-railway-sleepers.html|work=Polywood Inc|accessdate=20 March 2012}}</ref> and [[recycling|recycled]] rubber. Manufacturers claim a service life longer than wooden ties with an expected lifetime in the range of 30–80 years, that the ties are impervious to rot and [[insect]] attack,{{sfnp|Grant|2005|p=145}}{{sfnp|Harper|2002|p=742}}{{sfnp|La Mantia|2002|p=145}} and that they can be modified with a special relief on the bottom to provide additional lateral stability.{{sfnp|Grant|2005|p=145}} In some main track applications the hybrid plastic tie has a recessed design to be completely surrounded by ballast.
Aside from the environmental benefits of using recycled material, plastic ties usually replace timber ties soaked in creosote, the latter being a toxic chemical,{{sfnp|La Mantia|2002|p=277}} and are themselves recyclable.{{sfnp|Grant|2005|p=145}} Hybrid plastic railroad ties and composite ties are used in other rail applications such as underground mining operations,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.miningweekly.com/article.php?a_id=64354 |title=Polymer rail ties being tested for the mining industry|last=Cromberge|first=Peter|date=1 April 2005|publisher=Mining Weekly |accessdate=23 September 2010}}</ref> industrial zones, humid environments and densely populated areas. Hybrid railroad ties are also used to be partly exchanged with rotten wooden ties, which will result in continuous track stiffness. Hybrid plastic ties and composite ties also offer benefits on bridges and viaducts, because they lead to better distribution of forces and reduction of vibrations into respectively bridge girders or the ballast. This is due to better damping properties of hybrid plastic ties and composite ties, which will decrease the intensity of vibrations as well as the sound production.<ref>{{cite conference |first=Aran |last=Van Belkom |title=Analysis and comparison of sleeper parameters and the influence on track stiffness and performance |place=Edinburgh, UK |date=30 June 2015 |url=http://www.lankhorstrail.com/en/plastic-ties-railway }}</ref>
In 2009, Network Rail announced that it would begin replacing wooden ties with recycled plastic ones made by I-Plas Ltd of [[Halifax, West Yorkshire]];<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/road-and-rail-transport/5274149/Network-Rail-to-replace-wooden-sleepers-with-recycled-plastic.html |publisher= [[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]] |title=Network Rail to replace wooden sleepers with recycled plastic |date=4 May 2009 |accessdate=21 December 2012 }}</ref> but I-Plas became insolvent in October 2012.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://insolventcompanies.com/i-plas-limited/ |publisher = Insolvent Companies.com |date = 9 October 2012 |accessdate = 21 December 2012 |title = I-Plas Limited |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://archive.is/20130126120807/http://insolventcompanies.com/i-plas-limited/ |archivedate = 26 January 2013 |df = }}</ref>
The Cable TV series ''Factory Made'' has a segment on the manufacture of plastic ties.<ref>Factory Made 30 January 2012</ref>
In 2012, [[New Zealand]] ordered a trial batch of "EcoTrax" brand recycled composite ties from Axion for use on turnouts and bridges,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.railwaygazette.com/news/policy/single-view/view/final-phase-of-kiwirail-turnaround-funded.html?cHash=a7bf411a891ff8ae641b5f3b746aead6&sword_list%5B%5D=plastic&sword_list%5B%5D=sleeper&no_cache=1|title=Final phase of KiwiRail turnaround funded|last=|first=|date=|work=Railway Gazette|access-date=2018-08-01|language=en}}</ref><ref>[[Track & Signal]] Autumn 2013, p23</ref> and a further 3-year order in 2015,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.recyclingtoday.com/article/axion-new-zealand-plastics-contract/|title=Axion secures $8 million contract for recycled railroad ties in New Zealand|last=|first=|date=|work=Recycling Today|access-date=2018-08-01|language=en}}</ref> but then Axion filed for bankruptcy in December 2015,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/753048/000114420416103385/v440372_8k.htm|title=AXION INTERNATIONAL HOLDINGS, INC.|last=|first=|date=May 18, 2016|website=US SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> though it continues to trade.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.axionsi.com/products-composite-railroad-ties/|title=ECOTRAX® Composite Railroad Ties for Main Line, Road Crossings, Tunnels, Bridges, Switches & Turnouts|date=2016-05-31|access-date=2018-08-01|language=en}}</ref> These ties are developed by Dr. Nosker at Rutgers University.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/axion-international-files-for-bankruptcy-to-sell-assets-1449099105 |publisher=WSJ.com |date=2 December 2012 |title=Axion International Files for Bankruptcy to Sell Assets }}</ref>
In 2014 the KLP Hybrid Plastic Tie, by Lankhorst Engineered Products of [[Sneek]], [[Netherlands]], won the [[:de:Privatbahn Magazin|Privatbahn Magazin]] Innovation Award in the category Track and Infrastructure.<ref>{{cite press release |url= http://www.privatbahn-magazin.de/prima-cms/cms/download.php?cat=60_Presse&file=PriMa_Innovationspreis_2014_Gewinner.pdf |format=PDF |title=Privatbahn Magazin grants "Innovation Award 2014" |date=13 March 2015 }}</ref> <ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.lankhorstrail.com/de/aktuell/2015|title = Recessed hybrid plastic ties}}</ref>
Ties may also be made from [[fiberglass]].<ref>[[Trains]] magazine, February 2012, p18</ref>
==Non-conventional tie forms==
===Y-shaped ties=== [[File:Gleise y normal stahlschwellen.jpg|Y tie track next to conventional track|thumb]] An unusual form of tie is the Y-shaped tie, first developed in 1983. Compared to conventional ties the volume of ballast required is reduced due to the load-spreading characteristics of the Y-tie.<ref name="ob"/> Noise levels are high but the resistance to track movement is very good.<ref>{{cite report|url=http://www.promain.org/images/counsil/08_Selection_of_Tack_Systems.pdf|title=Innovative Track Systems: Criteria for their Selection|last1=Ogilvie|first1=Nigel|last2=Quante|first2=Franz|date=17 October 2001|publisher=ProMain|accessdate=23 September 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727185702/http://www.promain.org/images/counsil/08_Selection_of_Tack_Systems.pdf|archivedate=27 July 2011|df=}}</ref> For curves the three-point contact of a Y steel tie means that an exact geometric fit cannot be observed with a fixed attachment point.
The cross section of the ties is an [[I-beam]].<ref name="mb">{{cite web|url=http://pavement.wes.army.mil/papers/41/Paper41.pdf|title=Advanced track design|last=Budisa|first=Miodrag|accessdate=23 December 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110824034604/http://pavement.wes.army.mil/papers/41/Paper41.PDF|archivedate=24 August 2011|df=}}</ref>
As of 2006 less than {{convert|1,000|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} of Y-tie track had been built, of which approximately 90 percent is in [[Germany]].<ref name="ob">{{cite web |url=http://www.oberbauhandbuch.de/y-stahlschwelle.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20070814214300/http://www.oberbauhandbuch.de/y-stahlschwelle.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=14 August 2007 |title=Y-Stahlschwelle |author=February 28, 2006 |work=Some information derived from a lecture by Prof. Dr.-Ing. Karl Endmann |publisher=oberbauhandbuch.de |accessdate=18 September 2010 }}</ref>
===Twin ties=== The ZSX Twin tie is manufactured by Leonhard Moll Betonwerke GmbH & Co KG and is a pair of two pre-stressed concrete ties longitudinally connected by four steel rods.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.moll-betonwerke.de/downloads/MollZSX.pdf|title=ZSX Twin Sleeper|publisher=moll-betonwerke.de}}</ref> The design is said to be suitable for track with sharp curves, track subject to temperature stress such as that operated by trains with [[Eddy current brake|eddy brakes]], and bridges, and as transition track between traditional track and slab track or bridges.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gleisbau-welt.de/site/material/material_zwillingschwellen.html|title=ZSX Zwillingsschwelle—die besondere Spannbetonschwelle|publisher=gleisbau-welt.de|accessdate=23 December 2011|language=de|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120307231110/http://gleisbau-welt.de/site/material/material_zwillingschwellen.html|archive-date=2012-03-07|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
===Wide ties=== Concrete monoblock ties have also been produced in a wider form (e.g. {{convert|57|cm|inch|frac=8|abbr=on|disp=or}}) such that there is no ballast between the ties; this wide tie increases lateral resistance and reduces ballast pressure.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.railone.com/en/main-nav/products/railways-and-commuter-traffic/ballasted-track-systems/special-track-systems/wide-sleeper-track.html#c1707|title=Wide sleepers: so far, so good!|publisher=railone.com |accessdate=23 December 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pfleiderer-track.com/fileadmin/dateien/03_Broschueren/EN/breitschwelle_en.pdf|title=Wide sleeper track|publisher=RAIL.ONE GmbH|accessdate=23 December 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120307224156/http://www.pfleiderer-track.com/fileadmin/dateien/03_Broschueren/EN/breitschwelle_en.pdf|archivedate=7 March 2012|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pfleiderer-track.com/fileadmin/bilder/03_Download/Bilddatenbank/klein/TS_06.jpg |title=Image Ballasted wide sleeper |author= |work= |publisher=pfleiderer-track.com |accessdate= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110715071830/http://www.pfleiderer-track.com/fileadmin/bilder/03_Download/Bilddatenbank/klein/TS_06.jpg |archivedate=2011-07-15 |df= }}</ref> The system has been used in Germany<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0BQQ/is_5_43/ai_102286989/?tag=content;col1|title=Wide-sleeper track gains official approval |last1=Bachmann|first1=Hans|last2=Unbehaun|first2=Olaf|date=May 2003|journal=International Railway Journal|location=New York, New York|publisher=Simmons-Boardman Publishing Corporation|issn=2161-7376|accessdate=23 September 2010}}</ref> where wide ties have also been used in conjunction with the GETRAC A3 ballastless track systems.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.railone.com/en/main-nav/products/railways-and-commuter-traffic/ballastless-track-systems/getrac.html |title=Ballastless track system GETRAC—Asphalt in top form |publisher=railone.com|accessdate=24 December 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pfleiderer-track.com/fileadmin/bilder/03_Download/Bilddatenbank/klein/TS_05.jpg |title=Image Ballastless GETRAC A3 wide sleeper track system |author= |work= |publisher=pfleiderer-track.com |accessdate=23 September 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110715071850/http://www.pfleiderer-track.com/fileadmin/bilder/03_Download/Bilddatenbank/klein/TS_05.jpg |archivedate=15 July 2011 |df= }}</ref>
===Bi-block ties=== Bi-block (or twinblock) ties consist of two concrete rail supports joined by a steel bar. Advantages include increased lateral resistance and lower weight than monobloc concrete ties, as well as elimination of damage from torsional forces on the ties center due the more flexible steel connections.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.itb-tradetech.com/content/default.asp?page=7173|title=Traverses béton bi-blocs VDH|author=|work=|publisher=itb-tradetech.com|accessdate=23 September 2010|language=fr|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713064604/http://www.itb-tradetech.com/content/default.asp?page=7173|archivedate=13 July 2011|df=}}</ref> This tie type is in common use in France,{{sfnp|Bonnett|2005|p=64}} and are used on the high-speed [[TGV]] lines.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://freeit.free.fr/The%20Civil%20Engineering%20Handbook,2003/0958%20ch60.pdf|chapter=Chapter 60. High-Speed Ground Transportation: Planning and Design Issues|last1=Whitford|first1=Robert K.|last2=Karlaftis|first2=Matthew|last3=Kepaptsoglou|first3=Konstantinos|at=Table 60.6 TGV Infrastructure Characteristics for Southeastern and Atlantique Routes|title=The Civil Engineering Handbook|series=New Directions in Civil Engineering|edition=2nd|editor1-last=Chen|editor1-first=Wai-Fah|editor2-last=Liew|editor2-first=J.Y. Richard|year=2003|location=Boca Raton, Florida|publisher=CRC Press|isbn=0-8493-0958-1|oclc=248368514|accessdate=24 December 2011}}</ref> Bi-block ties are also used in ballastless track systems.{{sfnp|Bonnett|2005|p=64}}
===Frame ties=== Frame ties (German: ''Rahmenschwelle'') comprise both lateral and longitudinal members in a single monolithic concrete casting.<ref name="mb"/> This system is in use in [[Austria]];<ref name="mb"/> in the Austrian system the track is fastened at the four corners of the frame, and is also supported midway along the frame. Adjacent frame ties are butted close to each other. Advantages of this system over conventional cross increased support of track. In addition, construction methods used for this type of track are similar to those used for conventional track.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://trbrail.com/pdfs/LTK/Session2DaveStaplin/Sess2Pres1Rev1WashingtonII2.pdf |title=Fieldexperience with frame–tie-constructions |author=Klaus Riessberger |date=January 2004 |work=Institute for Railway Engineering and Transport Economy |publisher=trbrail.com |accessdate=22 September 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717093600/http://trbrail.com/pdfs/LTK/Session2DaveStaplin/Sess2Pres1Rev1WashingtonII2.pdf |archive-date=2011-07-17 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
===Ladder track=== {{Main|Ladder track}} In ladder track the ties are laid parallel to the rails and are several [[meter]]s long. The structure is similar to [[Isambard Kingdom Brunel|Brunel's]] baulk track; these longitudinal ties can be used with ballast, or with [[elastomer]] supports on a solid non-ballasted support.
==Fastening rails to railroad ties== {{Main|rail fastening systems}}
Various methods exist for fixing the rail to the railroad ties. Historically spikes gave way to cast iron chairs fixed to the tie, more recently springs (such as [[Pandrol clip]]s) are used to fix the rail to the tie chair.
==Other uses== [[File:Northfield railway station class 323 and sleepers.jpg|thumb|Wooden ties recycled as [[sculpture]]s at [[Northfield railway station]]]] [[File:Stone railway sleeper block.JPG|thumb|left|Stone block from the [[Scotch gauge]] [[Ardrossan Railway]] used to construct a loading dock]] In recent years, wooden railroad ties have also become popular for [[gardening]] and [[landscaping]], both in creating [[retaining wall]]s and raised-bed gardens, and sometimes for building steps as well. Traditionally, the ties sold for this purpose are decommissioned ties taken from rail lines when replaced with new ties, and their lifespan is often limited due to rot. Some entrepreneurs sell new ties. Due to the presence of wood [[preservative]]s such as [[coal tar]], [[creosote]] or [[salt (chemistry)|salt]]s of [[heavy metals]], railroad ties introduce an extra element of [[soil]] [[pollution]] into gardens and are avoided by many property owners. In the UK, new [[oak]] beams of the same size as standard railroad ties, but not treated with dangerous chemicals, are now available specifically for garden construction. They are about twice the price of the recycled product. In some places, railroad ties have been used in the construction of homes, particularly among those with lower incomes, especially near railroad tracks, including railroad employees. They are also used as [[Crib pier|cribbing]] for [[Dock (maritime)|docks]] and [[boathouses]].
The Spanish artist [[Agustín Ibarrola]] has used recycled ties from [[Renfe Operadora|Renfe]] in several projects.
In Germany, use of wooden railroad ties as building material (namely in gardens, houses and in all places where regular contact to human skin would be likely, in all areas frequented by children and in all areas associated with the production or handling of food in any way) has been prohibited by law since 1991 because they pose a significant risk to health and environment. From 1991 to 2002, this was regulated by the ''Teerölverordnung'' ([[Carbolineum]] By-law), and since 2002 has been regulated by the ''[[:de:Chemikalien-Verbotsverordnung|Chemikalien-Verbotsverordnung]]'' (Chemicals Prohibition By-law), §1 and Annex, Parts 10 and 17.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bundesrecht.juris.de/chemverbotsv/index.html|title=Chemikalien-Verbotsverordnung|author=|work=|publisher=Bundesministerium der Justiz|accessdate=23 September 2010|language=de|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100905103537/http://bundesrecht.juris.de/chemverbotsv/index.html|archive-date=2010-09-05|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
==Ballastless track== [[File:Schwellen Rheda.jpg|thumb|Slab track, System "Rheda 2000", prior to concrete pouring]]{{Main articles|Ballastless track}} [[File:Feste Fahrbahn FFBögl.jpg|thumb|Slab track, System "FF Bögl" on [[Nuremberg–Munich high-speed railway|Nuremberg–Munich high-speed rail line]]]] [[File:Slab track at St Pancras.jpg|thumb|Slab track at [[St Pancras station]]]]
Ballastless track does not require underlying ballast to maintain its integrity. The first such tracks were used for mountain railways (such as the [[Pilatus Railway]], built in 1889), with the rails being attached directly to the mountain rock. From the late 1960s onwards, [[Germany|German]], [[UK|British]], [[Switzerland|Swiss]] and [[Japan]]ese railways experimented with alternatives to the traditional railroad tie, in an effort to create track with greater accuracy and longevity, along with lower maintenance costs.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Eisenmann|first1=J.|last2=Leykauf|first2=G.|editor-first=J|editor-last=Eibl|chapter=Feste Fahrbahn für Schienenbahnen|title=Betonkalender 2000|volume=2|publisher=Ernst & Sohn|location=Berlin|year=2000|pages=291–298|isbn=978-3-433-01427-1|language=de}}</ref>
This gave rise to the ballastless railway track, especially in tunnels, on high-speed railway lines, and on lines where high train frequency imposes greater stress on the track. Paved concrete track<ref>Or PCT, or PACT</ref> has the rail fastened directly to a [[concrete]] slab about a {{convert|1/2|m|in|spell=in|sp=us}} thick,<ref name="krylov177">{{cite book | last = Krylov | first = V. V. | title = Noise and vibration from high-speed trains | publisher = Thomas Telford | location = London | year = 2001 | isbn = 0727729632 |page=177}}</ref> without ties. A similar but less expensive alternative is to accurately position concrete ties and then pour a [[concrete slab]] between and around them. This method is called "cast-in precast sleeper track".<ref>Bonnett 2005, pp. 79–80</ref>
These systems offer the advantage of superior stability and almost complete absence of deformation. Ballastless track systems incur significantly lower [[Track (rail transport)#Maintenance|maintenance]] costs compared to ballasted track.<ref name="krylov177"/><ref name="cook233">Cook 1988, p. 233.</ref> Due to the absence of any ballast, damage by flying ballast is eliminated, something that occurs at speeds in excess of {{convert|250|km/h|mph|0|abbr=on}}. It is also useful in renovating existing [[railroad tunnel]]s. Because slab track allows shallower construction than ballasted track, it may provide the extra overhead clearance necessary for converting a line to [[overhead lines|overhead electrification]], or allow the passage of trains with a greater [[loading gauge]].<ref name="bonnett78">Bonnett 2005, p. 78</ref>
Building a slab track is more expensive than building traditional ballasted track,<ref name="cook233"/><ref name="bonnett78" /> which has slowed its introduction outside of [[high-speed rail]] lines. Slab track is also difficult to modify after it has been installed,<ref name="bonnett78"/> and the curing time of concrete makes it difficult to convert an existing, busy railway line to a ballastless set-up.<ref name="cook233"/>
Slab track can also generate significantly more [[noise pollution]] and cause more [[vibration]] than traditional ballasted track. While this is partly attributable to slab track's decreased [[sound absorption]] qualities, a more significant factor is that slab track typically uses softer rail fasteners to provide vertical compliance similar to ballasted track, and these can lead to more noise, because they permit the rail to [[vibration|vibrate]] over a greater length.<ref name="krylov177"/>
Where it is critical to reduce noise and vibration, the concrete slab can be supported on soft resilient bearings. This configuration, called "floating slab track", is expensive and requires more depth or height in the track structure,<ref name="bonnett78"/> but it can reduce noise and vibration by around 80%.{{Clarify|reason=80%compared to what?|date=December 2009}}<ref>Lancaster 2001, p. 22</ref> GERB quote up to 35-40dB of attenuation using their steel sprung system<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.railway-technology.com/contractors/noise/gerb-vibration-control-systems/|title=GERB Vibration Control Systems - Floating Slab Track Systems - Railway Technology|website=www.railway-technology.com|access-date=2017-10-21}}</ref>. Alternatively, the rail can be supported along its length by an elastic material; when combined with a smaller rail section, this can provide a significant noise reduction over traditional ballasted track.<ref name="krylov177"/>

'''Retrograde condensation''' occurs when [[gas]] in a tube is compressed beyond the point of condensation with the effect that the liquid evaporates again. This is the opposite of [[condensation]]: the so-called retrograde condensation.
==Description== If the volume of two gases that are kept at constant [[temperature]] and [[pressure]] below [[supercritical fluid|critical conditions]] is gradually reduced, condensation will start. When a certain volume is reached, the amount of condensation will gradually increase upon further reduction in volume until the gases are liquefied. If the composition of the gases lies between their true and pseudo [[Critical point (thermodynamics)|critical point]]s the condensate formed will disappear on continued reduction of volume.<ref>[http://www.knaw.nl/waals/pdf/Com4_Kuenen2.pdf On retrogade condensation and the critical phenomena of mixtures of two substances]{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>[http://www.knaw.nl/waals/pdf/Com8_Kuenen.pdf On the abnormal phenomena near the critical point]{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> This disappearance of condensation is called retrograde condensation.
Because most [[natural gas]] found in [[petroleum reservoir]]s is not a pure product, when non-associated gas is extracted from a field under supercritical pressure/temperature conditions (i.e., the pressure in the reservoir decreases below [[dewpoint]]), [[Natural-gas condensate|condensate]] liquids may form during the [[Isothermal process|isothermic]] depressurizing, an effect called retrograde condensation.
==Discovery== [[Johannes Petrus Kuenen]] discovered retrograde condensation and published his findings in April 1892 with the title "Metingen betreffende het oppervlak van Van der Waals voor mengsels van koolzuur en chloormethyl" (Measurements on the [[Van der Waals surface]] for mixtures of [[carbonic acid]] and [[methyl]] [[chloride]]).<ref>[http://de.scientificcommons.org/2421376 Metingen betreffende het oppervlak van Van der Waals voor mengsels van koolzuur en chloormethyl]</ref><ref>[http://www.knaw.nl/waals/pdf/Com4_Kuenen.pdf Measurements on the surface of Van der Waals for mixtures of carbonic acid and methyl chloride] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050518021853/http://www.knaw.nl/waals/pdf/Com4_Kuenen.pdf |date=2005-05-18 }}</ref>

'''SiC–SiC matrix composite''' is a particular type of [[ceramic matrix composite]] (CMC) which have been accumulating interest mainly as high temperature materials for use in applications such as gas turbines, as an alternative to metallic [[alloy]]s. CMCs are generally a system of [[Composite material|material]]s that are made up of ceramic fibers or particles that lie in a [[ceramic]] matrix phase. In this case, a SiC/SiC composite is made by having a SiC ([[silicon carbide]]) matrix phase and a fiber phase incorporated together by different processing methods. Outstanding properties of SiC/SiC composites include high [[thermal]], [[Mechanics|mechanical]], and chemical stability while also providing high strength to [[weight ratio]].<ref name ="Naslain">Naslain, R. R. (2005), SiC-Matrix Composites: Nonbrittle Ceramics for Thermo-Structural Application. International Journal of Applied Ceramic Technology, 2: 75–84. doi: 10.1111/j.1744-7402.2005.02009.x</ref>
== Processing == SiC/SiC composites are mainly processed through three different methods. However, these processing methods are often subjected to variations in order to create the desired structure or property:<ref name="Naslain"/> # '''Chemical Vapor Infiltration (CVI)''' – The CVI method uses a gas phase SiC precursor to first grow SiC whiskers or nanowires in a preform, using conventional techniques developed with CVD. Following the growth of the fibers, the gas is again infiltrated into the preform to densify and create the matrix phase. Generally, the densification rate is slow during CVI, thus this process creates relatively high residual porosity (10–15%).<ref name="Naslain"/><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Yang | first1 = W. | last2 = Araki | first2 = H. | last3 = Kohyama | first3 = A. | last4 = Thaveethavorn | first4 = S. | last5 = Suzuki | first5 = H. | last6 = Noda | first6 = T. | doi = 10.1016/j.matlet.2004.05.059 | title = Fabrication in-situ SiC nanowires/SiC matrix composite by chemical vapour infiltration process | journal = Materials Letters | volume = 58 | issue = 25 | pages = 3145 | year = 2004 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref> # '''Polymer Impregnation and Pyrolysis (PIP)''' – The PIP method uses polymeric SiC precursors to infiltrate into a fiberous preform to create a SiC matrix. This method yields low stoichiometry as well as crystallinity due to the polymer-to-ceramic conversion process. Additionally, shrinkage also occurs during this conversion process, resulting in 10–20% residual porosity. Multiple infiltrations can be performed to compensate for the shrinkage.<ref>Nannetti, C. A., Ortona, A., de Pinto, D. A. and Riccardi, B. (2004), Manufacturing SiC-Fiber-Reinforced SiC Matrix Composites by Improved CVI/Slurry Infiltration/Polymer Impregnation and Pyrolysis. Journal of the American Ceramic Society, 87: 1205–1209. doi: 10.1111/j.1551-2916.2004.tb20093.x</ref> # '''Melt Infiltration (MI)''' – The MI method has several variations, including using a dispersion of SiC particulate slurry to infiltrate into the fiberous preform, or using CVI to coat carbon on the SiC fibers, followed with infiltrating liquid Si to react with the carbon to form SiC. With these methods, chemical reactivity, melt viscosity, and wetting between the two components should be considered carefully. Some issues with infiltrating melted Si is that the free Si can lower the composite's resistance to oxidation and creep. However, this technique usually yields lower residual porosity (~5%) compared to the other two techniques due to higher densification rates.<ref name="Naslain"/><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Brennan | first1 = J. J. | title = Interfacial characterization of a slurry-cast melt-infiltrated SiC/SiC ceramic-matrix composite | doi = 10.1016/S1359-6454(00)00248-2 | journal = Acta Materialia | volume = 48 | issue = 18–19 | pages = 4619–4628 | year = 2000 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref><ref>Hillig, W. B. (1988), Melt Infiltration Approach to Ceramic Matrix Composites. Journal of the American Ceramic Society, 71: C-96–C-99. doi: 10.1111/j.1151-2916.1988.tb05840.x</ref>
== Properties == === Mechanical properties === Mechanical properties of CMCs, including SiC–SiC composites can vary depending on the properties of their various components, namely, the fiber, matrix, and interphases. For example, the size, composition, crystallinity, or alignment of the fibers will dictate the properties of the composite. The interplay between matrix microcracking and fiber-matrix debonding often dominates the failure mechanism of SiC/SiC composites. This results in SiC/SiC composites having non-brittle behavior despite being fully ceramic. Additionally, creep rates at high temperatures are also extremely low, but still dependent on its various constituents.<ref name="Naslain"/><ref>Hinoki, Tatsuya, Edgar Lara-Curzio, and Lance L. Snead. "Mechanical properties of high purity SiC fiber-reinforced CVI-SiC matrix composites." Fusion science and technology 44 (2003): 211–218.</ref>
=== Thermal properties === SiC–SiC composites have a relatively high thermal conductivity and can operate at very high temperatures due to their inherently high creep and oxidation resistance. Residual porosity and stoichiometry of the material can vary its thermal conductivity, with increasing porosity leading to lower thermal conductivity and presence of Si–O–C phase also leading to lower thermal conductivity. In general, a typical well processed SiC–SiC composite can achieve a thermal conductivity of around 30 W/m-K at 1000 Celsius.<ref name="Naslain"/>
=== Chemical properties === Since SiC–SiC composites are generally sought for in high temperature applications, their oxidation resistance is of high importance. The oxidation mechanism for SiC–SiC composites vary depending on the temperature range, with operation in the higher temperature range (>1000 °C) being more beneficial than at lower temperatures (<1000 °C). In the former case, passive oxidation generates a protective oxide layer wheres in the latter case, oxidation degrades the fiber-matrix interface. Nonetheless, oxidation is an issue and environmental barrier coatings are being investigated to address this issue.<ref name="Naslain"/>

[[File:Sodium_tungsten_bronze.jpg|thumb|alt=Photograph of three crystals of sodium tungsten bronze|Three crystals of sodium tungsten bronze, showing its lustre and colouration.]] '''Sodium tungsten bronze''' is a form of [[Intercalation (chemistry)|insertion compound]] with the formula Na<sub>''x''</sub>WO<sub>3</sub>, where ''x'' is equal to or less than 1.<!-- see ref "G&E" --> Named due to its metallic lustre, its electrical properties range from [[semiconducting]] to metallic depending on the concentration of sodium ions present; it can also exhibit [[superconductivity]].
==History== Prepared in 1823 by the chemist [[Friedrich Wöhler]], sodium tungsten bronze was the first alkali metal bronze to be discovered.<ref>{{cite book | last = Hagenmuller | first = P | pages = 541–605 | chapter= Chapter 50: Tungsten bronzes, vanadium bronzes, and related compounds | title = Comprehensive Inorganic Chemistry | volume = 4 | publisher = [[Pergamon]] | year = 1973 | isbn = 978-0-08-016989-7 }}</ref> They owe some of their properties to the relative stability of the [[Tungsten|tungsten(V)]] cation that is formed.<ref name = "G&E">{{cite book | last1 = Greenwood | first1 = N. N. | last2 = Earnshaw | first2 = A. | title = Chemistry of the Elements | edition = 1st | date = 1993 | origyear = Reprint of corrected version of 1986, original version printed 1984 | publisher = Pergamon Press | isbn = 0-08-022057-6 | pages = 1185–6 | lastauthoramp = y }}</ref> A similar family of [[molybdenum bronze]]s may have been discovered in 1885 by [[Alfred Stavenhagen]] and E. Engels,<ref name=Stavenhagen/> but they are formed in a very narrow range of temperatures and were not reported again until the 1960s.<ref name=Wold/>
==Properties== Sodium tungsten bronze, like other tungsten bronzes, is resistant to chemical reaction under both acidic and basic conditions. Colour is dependent upon the proportion of sodium in the compound, ranging from golden at ''x''≈0.9, through red, orange and deep purple, to blue-black when ''x''≈0.3.
The electrical resistivity of the bronze depends on the proportion of sodium in the compound, with specific resistances of 1.66 mΩ being measured for some samples.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Straumanis | first1 = M. E. | title = The Sodium Tungsten Bronzes. II. The Electrical Conductivity of the Bronzes | last2 = Dravnieks | first2 = A. | journal = Journal of the American Chemical Society | volume = 71 | issue = 2 | pages = 683 | year = 1949 | doi = 10.1021/ja01170a086 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref> It has been suggested that electrons, released when the sodium atoms are ionised, are conducted readily through the tungsten t<sub>2g</sub> and oxygen π orbitals.<ref name = "G&E" /> This can be observed in the [[X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy|XPS]]<ref name= West>{{Cite book | last1 = West | first1 = Anthony | title = Solid state chemistry and its applications | date = 1984 | publisher = Wiley | isbn = 0-471-90874-6 | page = 96 }}</ref> and [[Ultraviolet photoelectron spectroscopy|UPS]]<ref name = Cheetham>{{Cite book | last1 = Cheetham | first1 = A K. | last2 = Day | first2 = P. | title = Solid state chemistry: techniques | date = 1987 | publisher = Clarendon | isbn = 0-19-855286-6 | page = 110 }}</ref> spectra: the peak representing the tungsten 5''d'' [[Band theory|band]] becomes more intense as ''x'' rises.
For values of ''x'' below 0.3, the bronze is semiconducting rather than metallic.<ref name = "G&E" /> When cooled sufficiently, sodium tungsten bronze becomes a [[superconductor]], with the critical temperature (''T<sub>c</sub>'') for Na<sub>0.23</sub>WO<sub>3</sub> being approximately 2.2 [[kelvin]].<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Ostenson | first1 = J. | last2 = Shanks | first2 = H. | last3 = Finnemore | first3 = D. | title = Superconductivity in the tungsten bronzes | doi = 10.1016/0022-5088(78)90024-3 | journal = Journal of the Less Common Metals | volume = 62 | pages = 149 | year = 1978 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref> The first record of superconductivity in a tungsten bronze was in 1964, with a ''T<sub>c</sub>'' of 0.57 K.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Raub | first1 = C. | last2 = Sweedler | first2 = A. | last3 = Jensen | first3 = M. | last4 = Broadston | first4 = S. | last5 = Matthias | first5 = B. | title = Superconductivity of Sodium Tungsten Bronzes | doi = 10.1103/PhysRevLett.13.746 | journal = Physical Review Letters | volume = 13 | issue = 25 | pages = 746 | year = 1964 | pmid = | pmc = | bibcode=1964PhRvL..13..746R}}</ref>
==Structure== [[File:Perovskite.jpg|thumb|alt=Drawing of the perovskite crystal structure|Structure of perovskite crystal structure with the formula ABX<sub>3</sub>.]] When ''x''=1, sodium tungsten bronze adopts a cubic phase: the [[Perovskite (structure)|perovskite]] crystal structure.<ref name = "Hägg">{{Cite journal | last1 = Hägg | first1 = G. | doi = 10.1038/135874b0 | title = The Spinels and the Cubic Sodium-Tungsten Bronzes as New Examples of Structures with Vacant Lattice Points | journal = Nature | volume = 135 | pages = 874 | year = 1935 | pmid = | pmc = |bibcode = 1935Natur.135..874H | issue=3421}}</ref> In this form, the structure consists of corner-sharing WO<sub>6</sub> octahedra with sodium ions in the interstitial gaps. For ''x'' values between 0.9 and 0.3, the structure remains similar but with an increasing deficiency of sodium ions and a smaller lattice parameter.<ref name = "Hägg" />
A number of other structure types can also be adopted, with varying electrical properties: cubic, tetragonal I and hexagonal phases are metallic, whereas orthorhombic and tetragonal II structures are semiconducting.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Ngai | first1 = K. L. | last2 = Reinecke | first2 = T. L. | title = Structural instabilities and superconductivity in the alkali tungsten bronzes | journal = Journal of Physics F: Metal Physics | volume = 8 | pages = 151 | year = 1978 | doi = 10.1088/0305-4608/8/1/018 | pmid = | pmc = |bibcode = 1978JPhF....8..151N }}</ref>
==Synthesis== Wöhler's 1823 synthesis involved reducing [[sodium tungstate]] and [[tungsten trioxide]] with [[hydrogen gas]] at red heat. A more modern approach reduces a [[wiktionary:melt#Noun|melt]] of the reactants with electricity rather than with hydrogen.<ref name = "prep">{{Cite journal| last1 = Conroy | first1 = L. E. | doi = 10.1021/ed054p45 | title = The preparation and characterization of a sodium tungsten bronze. An inorganic experiment | journal = Journal of Chemical Education | volume = 54 | page = 45| year = 1977 | pmid = | pmc = |bibcode = 1977JChEd..54...45C }}</ref> Microwave synthesis is also possible,<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Guo | first1 = J. | last2 = Dong | first2 = C. | last3 = Yang | first3 = L. | last4 = Fu | first4 = G. | title = A green route for microwave synthesis of sodium tungsten bronzes NaWO (0<<1) | doi = 10.1016/j.jssc.2004.10.017 | journal = Journal of Solid State Chemistry | volume = 178 | pages = 58 | year = 2005 | pmid = | pmc = |bibcode = 2005JSSCh.178...58G }}</ref> using tungsten powder as the reducing agent. Hydrothermal (both batch and flow) syntheses are also possible.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Luo|first1=Jia Yu|last2=Liu|first2=Jing Xiao|last3=Shi|first3=Fei|last4=Xu|first4=Qiang|last5=Jiang|first5=Yan Yan|last6=Liu|first6=Gui Shan|last7=Hu|first7=Zhi Qiang|title=Synthesis of Sodium Tungsten Bronze via Hydrothermal Method Assisted by Citric Acid|journal=Advanced Materials Research|date=June 2013|volume=712–715|pages=280–283|doi=10.4028/www.scientific.net/AMR.712-715.280}}</ref>
==Related compounds== The sodium in this compound can be replaced by other [[alkali metals]] to form their tungsten bronzes, and by other metals such as tin and lead.<ref>{{cite book | last1 = Smart | first1 = Lesley E. | last2 = Moore | first2 = Elaine A. | title = Solid State Chemistry: An Introduction | edition = 3rd | date = 2005 | publisher = CRC Press | isbn = 0-7487-7516-1 | page = 227 | lastauthoramp = }}</ref> Molybdenum bronzes also exist but are less stable than their tungsten counterparts.<ref name= "G&E" />

J. | last4 = Ferreti | first4 = A. | year = 1964 | title = Preparation and properties of sodium and potassium molybdenum bronze crystals | url = | journal = Inorganic Chemistry | volume = 3 | issue = 4| pages = 545–547 | doi = 10.1021/ic50014a022 }}</ref> }}

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Steels}} '''Spring steel''' is a name given to a wide range of [[steel|steels]]{{cite web |last1=Engineering.com |url=http://www.engineering.com/Library/ArticlesPage/tabid/85/ArticleID/134/Springs.aspx |title=Springs |date=2006-10-23}} used in the manufacture of [[Spring (device)|springs]], prominently in [[automobile|automotive]] and industrial suspension applications. These steels are generally [[Alloy steel#Low-alloy Steels|low-alloy]] [[manganese]], [[medium-carbon steel]] or [[high-carbon steel]] with a very high [[yield strength]]. This allows objects made of [[Spring (device)|spring]] steel to return to their original shape despite significant deflection or twisting. ==Grades== Many grades of steel can be hardened and tempered to suit application as a spring; however, some steels exhibit more desirable characteristics for spring applications. {| class="wikitable" |+ Common spring steel grades |- ! rowspan=2 | SAE grade

{{notability|date=February 2010}} '''Ribbon''' solar cells are a 1970s technology most recently sold by [[Evergreen Solar]] (which is now in receivership, i.e. bankrupt and liquidated), among other manufacturers.
==Technology description==
Ribbon growth is a method of producing [[multi-crystalline silicon]] strips suitable for the [[photovoltaic industry]].
The name describes the manufacturing process, where a sheet of silicon [[the ribbon]] is pulled vertically from a bath of [[molten]] silicon to form a multi-crystalline [[silicon crystal]]s. The ribbon is then cut into lengths which are treated with traditional processes to form [[solar cell]]s. The process was developed in the 1970s by Mobil-Tyco, Solar Energy Corp., Energy Materials, Corp., Motorola and IBM. Ribbons 4-5 inches wide and less than 1/100th of an inch thick were made. It is similar to the dendrite process, developed by Westinghouse in the 1970s, which had the further advantage of having no ribbon (graphite or ceramic die), using only two special seed crystals, or "dendrites," which were dipped side by side into molten silicon and pulled up slowly. These demonstrated efficiencies upwards of 16% by 1980.<ref>"Photovoltaics - Sunlight to Electricity in One Step." Paul Maycock, Edward Stirewalt. Brick House Publishing Co, Andover, Mass. 1981.</ref>
Ribbon growth has the capability of using less silicon compared to other [[wafer]] production methods as wafers are manufactured to the approximately correct specification avoiding the need for sawing of silicon blocks. Silicon accounts for more than 50% of manufacturing costs in producing first generation solar cells, where much of the silicon is discarded as waste at the sawing stage of manufacture. Employing the string ribbon process allows the manufacture of PV grade silicon wafers to the approximate dimensions while avoiding the waste encountered when sawing wafers from ingots. This manufacturing process uses about half the amount of input silicon required by traditional processes.
String Ribbon technology is a technique where the ribbon is pulled from the silicon melt between two wires, it is not capable of achieving the same electrical performance as conventional wafer technology. Typically a cut wafer will convert 18-20% of the incoming light into electricity where String Ribbon Solar Cells are capable of converting 13-14%. In research laboratories the technology has reached as high as 18.3%, however it cannot be produced commercially to this specification.<ref>Fabrication and analysis of high-efficiency String Ribbon Si solar cells. K. Nakayashiki, B. Rounsaville, V. Yelundur, D.S. Kim, A. Rohatgi, R. Clark-Phelps, and J.I. Hanoka, Solid-State Electron. 50, 1406 (2006)</ref> Wafer technologies have reached as high as 25% in laboratory conditions.
While String Ribbon technology has certain advantages as to the shape of the crystals, the overall thickness varies enough so that not every 'silicon strip' can be processed directly into a solar cell. In addition to this drawback, the growth process is thermally very inefficient. The radiating area/gram of crystal is extremely high, leading to very high energy expenses which offset the reduced silicon use/expense.
==Production estimates==
{| class="wikitable" ! Year !! Production Capacity !! Production !! Installed Capacity |- | 2006 || - || 28 MW || - |- | 2007 || 107 MW || 66.2 MW || - |- | 2008 || 188 MW || 125 MW || |}

{{about|the Styrofoam brand}} [[File:Styrofoam_Insulation.jpg|thumb|right|STYROFOAM Brand Insulation extruded polystyrene foam (XPS), owned and manufactured by Dow.]]
'''Styrofoam''' is a [[trademark]]ed brand of closed-cell [[polystyrene#Extruded polystyrene foam|extruded polystyrene foam]] (XPS), commonly called "Blue Board" manufactured as foam continuous [[building insulation]] board used in walls, roofs, and foundations as [[thermal insulation]] and water barrier. This material is light blue in color and is owned and manufactured by [[The Dow Chemical Company]].<ref name="what-is-styrofoam">[https://web.archive.org/web/20080324134328/http://building.dow.com/styrofoam/what.htm Dow Chemical Company Styrofoam page]</ref>
In the [[United States]] and [[Canada]], the colloquial use of the word ''styrofoam'' refers to another material that is usually white in color and made of expanded (not extruded) [[polystyrene|polystyrene foam]] ([[Expanded polystyrene|EPS]]). It is often used in [[disposable]] coffee cups and coolers, and as [[cushioning]] material in [[packaging]].<ref name="what-is-styrofoam"/> The [[Generic trademark|trademarked term is used generically]] although it is a different material from the extruded polystyrene used for Styrofoam [[Thermal insulation|insulation]].
The Styrofoam brand polystyrene foam, which is used for craft applications, can be identified by its roughness and the "crunch" it makes when cut.{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} Additionally, it is moderately soluble in many organic solvents, [[super glue|cyanoacrylate]], and the propellants and solvents of [[spray paint]].
== History == In 1947,<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.google.com/patents/US2450436|title=Patent US 2450436 A. Manufacture of cellular thermoplastic products}}</ref> researchers in Dow's Chemical Physics Lab found a way to make foamed polystyrene. Led by [[Ray McIntire]], they rediscovered a method first used by [[Sweden|Swedish]] inventor [[Carl Georg Munters]].<ref>{{cite book | last = Boundy | first = Ray H. |author2=Amos, J. Lawrence | title = A History of the Dow Chemical Physics Lab | publisher = Marcel Dekker, Inc. | year = 1991 | location = New York | pages = 117–128 | isbn = 0-8247-8097-3}}</ref> Dow acquired exclusive rights to use Munters' patents and found ways to make large quantities of extruded polystyrene as a closed cell foam that resists moisture.
== Uses ==
Styrofoam has a variety of uses. Dow produces Styrofoam building materials, including varieties of [[building insulation]] sheathing and pipe insulation. The claimed [[R-value (insulation)|R-value]] of Styrofoam insulation is five per inch.<ref>[http://building.dow.com/media/news/2007/20071205a.htm Dow Announces New Technology for STYROFOAM Insulation]</ref>
Styrofoam can be used under roads and other structures to prevent soil disturbances due to freezing and thawing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://building.dow.com/na/en/applications/geotech/index.htm|title=Geotechnical applications of Styrofoam|publisher = Dow Chemical| accessdate=2009-10-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alaskool.org/resources/regional/nw_reg_pro/permafrost.html|title=Engineering considerations when building on permafrost|accessdate=2007-08-30}}</ref>
Styrofoam is composed of 98% air, making it lightweight and buoyant.<ref>{{cite web| url= http://www.forte-eps-solutions.com/styrofoam-sheets-polystyrene-insulation-difference-new-jersey-new-york-ontario-quebec.html|title= What is the Difference between EPS Polystyrene and (styrofoam)?}}</ref>
Dow also produces Styrofoam as [[structural insulated panel]]s for use by [[florist]]s and in craft products.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://craft.dow.com|title=STYROFOAM Brand Foam Crafts| accessdate=2010-12-31}}</ref> Dow insulation Styrofoam has a distinctive blue color; Styrofoam for craft applications is available in white and green.
== Environmental effects == The EPA and International Agency for Research on Cancer consider styrene a possible human [[carcinogen]].<ref>[http://www.epa.gov/chemfact/styre-sd.pdf epa.gov]</ref><ref>[http://www.inchem.org/documents/iarc/vol82/82-07.html inchem.org]</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2014}} {{Expand Russian|date=September 2018}}{{Infobox aircraft occurrence |name = Thai Airways International Flight 261 |occurrence_type = Accident |image = Thai Airways International Airbus A310 Hoppe.jpg |image_size = 200 |caption = A Thai Airways International Airbus A310 similar to the one involved in Flight 261 |date = {{start date|1998|12|11|df=y}} |summary = Stalled, spatial disorientation in inclement weather, pilot error |site = 0.7 km S of [[Surat Thani International Airport]] (URT) (Thailand) |coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LON|type:event|display=inline,title}} --> |aircraft_type = [[Airbus A310-204]] |aircraft_name = ''Phitsanulok'' |operator = [[Thai Airways|Thai Airways International]] |ICAO = THA261 |IATA = TG261 |callsign = THAI 261 |tail_number = HS-TIA |origin = [[Don Mueang International Airport]] (DMK) |destination = [[Surat Thani International Airport]] (URT) |occupants = 146 |passengers = 132 |crew = 14 |injuries = 45 |fatalities = 101 |survivors = 45 }}
'''Thai Airways International Flight 261 (TG261/THA261)''' was a scheduled domestic passenger flight from [[Bangkok]]'s [[Don Mueang International Airport]], [[Thailand]] to [[Surat Thani International Airport]] in [[Surat Thani]], Thailand. The flight was operated by [[Thai Airways|Thai Airways International]], the [[flag carrier]] of Thailand. On 11 December 1998, the aircraft, an [[Airbus]] [[Airbus A310|A310-204]] registered in Thailand as HS-TIA, stalled and crashed in a rice paddy on its landing attempt at Surat Thani Airport. A total of 101 people were killed in the crash.<ref name="ASN-1998">{{cite web |title=Database-1998 |url=https://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?id=19981211-0 |website=Aviation Safety Network (ASN) |publisher=Flight Safety Foundation |accessdate=10 September 2018}}</ref>
Thailand's [[Aircraft Accident Investigation Committee]] (AAIC) opened an investigation into the accident. The investigation revealed that the crew had become disoriented. Visibility was limited. Stress caused the crew to lose control of the aircraft. The AAIC noted also Surat Thani's minimal lighting<ref name="ASN-1998"/> and faulty warnings to the aircraft.
==Aircraft== HS-TIA was an [[Airbus A310-204]], c/n 415, previously registered as F-WWBI for flight testing with Airbus. Given the name ''Phitsanulok'', HS-TIA was first flown on 3 March 1986 and delivered to Thai Airways at Don Mueang on 29 April 1986.
==Nationalities== There were 25 foreigners on board the flight including nationalities from Austria, Australia, Britain, Finland, Germany, Japan, Norway, and the United States. Among the survivors were three Australians, three Japanese, three Germans, two Israelis and one Briton.<ref>{{cite news |title=Thai police stop search at crash site |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131217225344/http://www.lubbockonline.com/stories/121398/LA0562.shtml |accessdate=10 September 2018 |agency=AP|work=Lubbock Avalanche-Journal |date=1998-12-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Thai plane was missing equipment |url=http://www.lubbockonline.com/stories/121498/LA0783.shtml |accessdate=10 September 2018 |work=Lubbock Avalanche-Journal |agency=AP |date=1998-12-14}}</ref>
== Accident == Weather conditions were rainy at the time of the crash and the crew was unable to see the runway. At 19:05 local time, the aircraft was attempting to land on runway 22 for the third time following two aborted landings. The captain ordered another go-around attempt and when the pitch attitude reached approximately 48 degrees the aircraft entered an aerodynamic stall, began to lose altitude and crashed into the ground, bursting into flames. 101 of the 146 passengers and crew died at the scene. 45 were rushed to hospital.<ref name="ASN-1998" />
==Investigation== Airbus, the aircraft manufacturer, sent a team of specialists to assist Thai authorities in the crash investigation. Both the flight data recorder and the cockpit voice recorder were found by the search and rescue team and were taken from the crash site for further investigation.<ref>{{cite news|title=Grim task over |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/233653.stm|work=BBC|date=12 December 1998}}</ref> Investigators stated that bad weather was the probable cause of the accident, without ruling out pilot error. There was a project to extend the runway at Surat Thani Airport, however the project was delayed due to an economic downturn. A Thai air force pilot stated that due to the removal of the [[Instrument landing system]] (ILS), pilots had to use a radio navigation system which was less accurate.<ref name=BBC-19981213>{{citeweb|title=Thai crash victims compensation offer |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/234189.stm|work=BBC|date=13 December 1998}}</ref>
==Aftermath== Thai Airways International offered compensation payment to the families affected by the crash. Thai Airways International chairman, Thamnoon Wanglee, stated on a news conference that each relatives of the 101 victims of the crash would receive a compensation payment of US$100,000, while the 45 injured survivors would receive a compensation of 200,000 [[Thai baht|baht]] (US$5,600) each. The airline would pay their medical expenses.<ref name=BBC-19981213/>
==In popular culture== * ''[[Channel 9 MCOT HD|Modernine TV]]'' discussed Thai Airways International Flight 261 on ''TimeLine'', 30 May 2016, in "Flight 261 Disaster".<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Nm1V6is2DWs ข่าวดังข้ามเวลา : หายนะ..เที่ยวบิน 261 (30 พ.ค.2559)]</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Thailand|Aviation}} * [[One-Two-GO Airlines Flight 269]]

Earth's Climate Crisis & The Fate of Humanity | title_orig = | translator = | image = RevengeofGaiacover.jpg | caption = | author = [[James Lovelock]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = | language = | series = | subject = | genre = | publisher = Penguin Books | pub_date = 2007 | english_pub_date = | media_type = | pages = | isbn = 0-14-102597-2 | oclc = | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} [[File:CLAW hypothesis graphic 2 AYool.png|thumb|Schematic diagram of the anti-CLAW hypothesis (Lovelock, 2006)]] '''''The Revenge of Gaia: Why the Earth is Fighting Back – and How we Can Still Save Humanity''''' (2006) is a book by [[James Lovelock]]. Some editions of the book have a different, less optimistic subtitle: '''''Earth's Climate Crisis and the Fate of Humanity'''''. The book introduces the concept of the [[anti-CLAW hypothesis]]. Lovelock proposed that instead of providing negative feedback in the climate system, the components of the [[CLAW hypothesis]] may act to create a [[positive feedback|positive feedback loop]].{{cite book | author=Lovelock, James | title=The Revenge of Gaia | publisher=Penguin | year=2007 | isbn=0-14-102597-2}} Under future [[global warming]], increasing temperature may [[Stratification (water)|stratify]] the [[world ocean]], decreasing the supply of nutrients from the deep ocean to its [[primary production|productive]] [[euphotic zone]]. Consequently, [[phytoplankton]] activity will decline with a concomitant fall in the production of [[dimethyl sulfide]] (DMS). In a reverse of the CLAW hypothesis, this decline in DMS production will lead to a decrease in cloud condensation nuclei and a fall in cloud [[albedo]]. The consequence of this will be further climate warming which may lead to even less DMS production (and further climate warming). The figure to the right shows a summarising schematic diagram. Evidence for the anti-CLAW hypothesis is constrained by similar uncertainties as those of the sulfur cycle feedback loop of the CLAW hypothesis. However, researchers [[computer simulation|simulating]] future [[Primary production#Oceanic production|oceanic primary production]] have found evidence of declining production with increasing ocean stratification,{{cite journal |author=Cox, P. M., Betts, R. A., Jones, C. D., Spall, S. A. and Totterdell, I. '''Tórshavn''' ({{IPA-fo|ˈtʰɔuʂhaʊn|lang}}; <small>[[Literal translation|lit.]]</small> '[[Thor]]'s harbour'; {{lang-da|Thorshavn}}, {{IPA-da|ˈtoɐ̯ˀshɑwˀn|pron}}) is the [[Capital (political)|capital]] and largest town of the [[Faroe Islands]]. Tórshavn is in the southern part on the east coast of [[Streymoy]]. To the northwest of the city lies the {{convert|347|m|ft|adj=mid|-high|sp=us}} mountain [[Húsareyn]], and to the southwest, the {{convert|350|m|ft|adj=mid|-high|sp=us}} Kirkjubøreyn. They are separated by the Sandá River. The town proper has a population of 13,089 (2017), and the greater [[urban area]] a population of 21,000.
The Norse established their parliament on the [[Tinganes|Tinganes peninsula]] in AD 850.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.torshavn.fo/Default.aspx?pageid=620|title=Tórshavn Municipality|website=Tórshavn Municipality|publisher=}}</ref> Tórshavn thus became the capital of the Faroe Islands and has remained so ever since. All through the [[Middle Ages]] the narrow peninsula jutting out into the sea made up the main part of Tórshavn. Early on, Tórshavn became the centre of the islands' trade monopoly, thereby being the only legal place for the islanders to sell and buy goods. In 1856, the trade monopoly was abolished and the islands were left open to free trade.
== History == === Early history === {{Unreferenced section|date=February 2015}} It is not known whether the site of Tórshavn was of interest to the Celtic monks who were [[History of the Faroe Islands|probably the first settlers]] in the Faroes. The Viking settlers in the 9th century established their own parliaments, called ''[[Thing (assembly)|tings]]'', in different parts of the islands, it being the tradition in each case to hold the ''ting'' at a neutral and thus uninhabited place, so no one location gave anyone an advantage. The main ''ting'' for the islands was convoked in Tórshavn in 825, on [[Tinganes]], the [[peninsula]] that divides the harbour into two parts: ''Eystaravág'' and ''Vestaravág''. The Vikings would thus meet on the flat rocks of Tinganes every summer, as the most central place on the islands, although there was no settlement at Tinganes at that time. The [[Færeyinga Saga]] says: "the place of the ''ting'' of the Faroese was on Streymoy, and there is the harbour that is called Tórshavn". The Viking age ended in 1035. The ''ting'' was followed by a market which gradually grew into a permanent trading area.
All through the [[Middle Ages]], the narrow peninsula jutting out into the sea made up the main part of Tórshavn. It belonged to the outfield of two farmers. Unlike other Faroese villages, Tórshavn was never a distinct farming community. During the 12th century, all trade between Norway and the Faroes, along with other tributary islands to the west, became centralised in [[Bergen]]. In 1271, a royal trade monopoly was established in Tórshavn by the Norwegian Crown. According to a document from 1271, two ships would sail regularly to Tórshavn from Bergen with cargoes of salt, timber and cereal. Tórshavn therefore had more contact with the outside world than did the other villages. Under the Norwegian, and then Danish rule, government officials made Tórshavn their home. All of these things, combined with the fact that Tórshavn was the seat of the ''ting'' of the islands, influenced the town's development.
=== 1500–1800 === {{unreferenced section|date=February 2015}} [[File:Tórshavn skansin 8.jpg|thumb|Skansin has been rebuilt several times since it was first built in 1580. The current building dates back to 1790]]
Sources do not mention a built-up area in Tórshavn until after the Protestant reformation in 1539. In ca. 1580 a small fort, [[Skansin]], was built by the Faroese naval hero and trader [[Magnus Heinason]] at the north end of the harbour. Later small fortifications were built at Tinganes.
In 1584 Tórshavn had 101 inhabitants. The population was divided into three equally large groups made up of farmers, their families and servants, trade and government officials and people who owned no land and therefore not much else; this included the landless [[proletariat]] from the villages that during this period came to Tórshavn in search of work. They were set to guard duty on Skansin without pay, and for clothing and food they depended on the bounty of the farmers.
In 1655 king [[Frederick III of Denmark]] granted the Faroe Islands to his favourite [[Politician|statesman]] [[Kristoffer Gabel]], the rule of the von Gabel Family, 1655–1709, is known as ''Gablatíðin''. It is the darkest chapter in the history of Tórshavn. Gabel's administration suppressed the islanders in various ways. The trade monopoly was in the family's hands and it was not designed for the needs of the Faroese people. People across the country brought products into town and had to be satisfied with whatever price they were given. At the same time imported goods were limited and expensive. There came considerable complaints from the islands' inhabitants of unjust treatment by the civil administration in Tórshavn. These not only included the persons in charge of the monopoly trade, but also the [[bailiff]] and others. It was during this period, in 1673, that Tinganes was ravaged by a fire after a store of gunpowder kept at Tinganes had blown up. Many old houses burnt to the ground and old Faroese records were lost as were Gabel's documents.
Conditions improved in Tórshavn when the trade monopoly became a royal monopoly in 1709. The royal monopoly was supplied with goods from [[Copenhagen]] three times a year. However, in 1709 Tórshavn was hit by a plague of smallpox, killing nearly the entire population. The town had by this time reached a population of 300 and 250 of the inhabitants died. Still, it was during the latter half of the 18th century that Tórshavn started to develop into a small town. This was while Niels Ryberg was in charge of the trade monopoly. From 1768 and during the next 20 years onwards Ryberg was allowed to carry on an entrepot trade which was mainly based on smuggling to [[England]]. Because of the French-British conflict there was room for this kind of operation. In Tórshavn his warehouses filled up with goods. Ryberg was the first person who thought of making a financial profit from fishing, which later became the most important economic factor to the islands. He experimented with salted cod and herring but at this point in time nothing much beyond this happened.
[[Tórshavn Cathedral]] was first built in 1788 and partly rebuilt in 1865. Since 1990, it has been the seat of the Bishop of the Faroe Islands (in the [[Church of the Faroe Islands]]).
=== 1800–present === [[File:Recherche Expedition 1839 Tórshavn.jpg|thumb|left|Tórshavn in 1839]] On 30 March 1808, during the Anglo-Danish [[Gunboat War]], the [[Cruizer class brig-sloop]] [[HMS Clio (1807)|HMS ''Clio'']] entered Tórshavn and briefly captured the fort at Skansin. The fort surrendered without firing a shot as the landing party approached. The ''Clio'''s men [[Touch hole#Spiking the guns|spiked]] the fort's eight 18-pounder guns and took all the smaller guns and weapons before leaving. Shortly after 6 May a German privateer who had assumed the name "Baron von Hompesch" plundered the defenceless city and seized the property of the Danish Crown Monopoly. The Admiralty Prize Court, however, refused to condemn it as a lawful prize. {{citation needed|date=April 2015}} [[File:Logting 1864, faroe islands.jpg|thumb|Tórshavn in 1864, the Løgting is on top left]] In 1856, free trade came to the Faroe Islands. By opening the islands to the world, it transformed the economy, with Tórshavn at its centre. The farming land was rented to townspeople who could later buy it if they wished. These small plots of land enabled people to keep cows and sheep. {{citation needed|date=April 2015}}
In 1866, Tórshavn's town council was founded. The town has been the capital of the Faroe Islands ever since. Later, in 1909, Tórshavn became a market town with the same municipal charter as Danish market towns.
In 1927, Tórshavn had a modern harbour built. This made it possible for larger ships to berth.<ref name="Gregoriussen 11-15">{{Cite book|author=Gregoriussen, Jákup Pauli|year=2000|title=Tórshavn, vár miðstøð og borg II. Tekningar úr Havn|location=Velbastaður|publisher=Forlagið í Støplum|isbn=99918-914-4-7|language=fo|pages=11–15}}</ref>
During the [[British occupation of the Faroe Islands in World War II]], Skansin was used as the headquarters of the Royal Navy Command, and two 5.5-inch guns used aboard {{HMS|Furious|47|6}} before World War II were deployed.<ref>[http://www.navweaps.com/Weapons/WNBR_55-50_mk1.htm <nowiki>British 5.5"/50 (14 cm) BL Mark I</nowiki>]</ref>
In 1974, the neighbouring villages [[Hoyvík]] and [[Hvítanes]] were made part of the town area. Later, even more municipalities joined the Tórshavn municipality. In 1978 Kaldbak, in 1997 Argir, in 2001 Kollafjørður, and finally in 2005, Kirkjubøur, Hestur, and Nólsoy.
== Climate == [[File:Tórshavn.2009.5.jpg|thumb|Tórshavn Harbour Ferry Terminal, view towards [[Tinganes]] and 'Vesturbýur' ''The Western Town'']] Tórshavn features a [[subpolar oceanic climate]] (''Cfc'') with average summer highs around {{convert|12|C|F|abbr=on}} and average winter highs around {{convert|6|C|F|abbr=on}}, and with winter lows averaging just above freezing, and frequent cloudy skies. Average monthly precipitation is highest in autumn and winter, peaking in January, owing to frequent, intense storms crossing the area from the North Atlantic Ocean, while May and June are markedly drier months. Tórshavn is among the cloudiest places in the world, with significant sunshine records at only about 2.4 hours of sunshine per day; however, no data exists for places such as the [[Aleutian Islands]] or parts of [[Zona Austral|southern Chile]], which may have even less sun. {{Citation needed|date=December 2015}} Because of the cloudy weather and the ice-free water surrounding Torshavn, its winter temperatures are exceptionally mild for such a northerly location. Summer temperatures are much lower than those found in continental Scandinavia on similar parallels. The temperature amplitude in the period from 1961 to 2010 is a mere {{convert|33|C-change}} between the absolute warmest and coldest temperatures.
